conclusion: Cheating is unforgivable because it shows horrible character and lack of self control. Forgiving this shows lack of self respect.
premises: i noticed that cheating has been normalized especially with people of color poc in the media and in real life. it's sexist if you ask me. let me first define cheating. cheating is telling your partner you won't be having a sexual or romantic relationship outside your relationship, but still doing it. it's not considered cheating to me if it's an open relationship or you were forced with violence and whatnot. also, when talking of relationships, i mean mutual relationships that have or had love in them. i don't want to hear of forced marriages, abusive relationships, or bad arranged marriages cause those have a very different dynamic from what i'm thinking about. if the passion has died in your relationship, it is better to break off the relationship. i don't mean divorce though cause i know that involves money and can be messy, but people can acknowledge the death of a relationship and separate at least. to me, if you cheat that means you don't love your so. if you really love your so and understand the pain it would cause them, you wouldn't consider cheating. if your so is having problems sexually and you cheat, that's basically showing that sexual satisfaction was more important than the emotional bond you shared. there's also many ways to attempt to resolve this issue. and if it's that big of a deal and unsolvable, you can move on to an open relationship or seperate break up. people who take back those who cheat come off as extremely desperate for the financial benefits in the relationship and or the emotional support they felt in the relationship. i feel when people take back people who cheat, it's because they don't feel they'll ever find anyone to replace what they had which can be a valid point, but still sad desperate . imo i feel it's a better bet to live the rest of your life without a cheater than with someone who will disrespect your emotions like that. i feel this all makes perfect sense, but it's like the older i get the more people are acting like i'm living in fantasy land. beautiful independent women are taking back horrible men after cheating with multiple women. great men are taking back women who cheat too. what's going on?

auto_conc: it's better to break up with your partner than to continue the relationship with them.
gt: an aspect of forgiveness for cheating that many most? people consistently undervalue is that while cheating is a horrible thing to do to a person, it doesn't necessarily disregard the entire history that two people may have shared together. i've seen several older couples that find out one of the people cheated over decades. to be sure, once that knowledge is out, the relationship is forever changed. also note, that there was a huge discrepancy in the two people's understandings of what the relationship was to begin with. one person thought they were both being faithful, the other spent a significant amount of energy hiding some amount of their activities from their partner. once cheating becomes known, the relationship cannot be what it was, because it wasn't what it was claiming to be before that point anyway. to get back to why someone might forgive a cheater and it's ok: have you tried dating people? 90 of the people you will find in the dating pool are just not a good match for you, and a significant portion of those people are just not ready for a meaningful relationship to begin with. comparing that to a partner who cheated, in a simple pros cons format, will often place the cheater on the better side of the comparison, even with the huge 'cheated on me' con. the relationship likely had many positives before the cheating was known, and most of those positives haven't changed. ie: if the partner was worth staying with before the cheating and actively making the subjects life better, then once the cheating is known, they aren't making the subjects life as good as they once were, but it's still a net positive. going back to the older couples, sometimes it just isn't worth it to go back into the dating pool, you simply don't have enough time left in this world for it to be worth it. you might argue that is because they are showing less self respect, but i would argue that is merely accepting the facts of life. the world is what it is and you can do a simple math analysis on how many years it takes to get to a point of trust with a person. clearly, a cheater has ruined a significant amount of trust, especially physical intimacy, but relationships are about a lot more than that, and a truly sorry cheater can spend the rest of their years how many years is that anyway? making it up to their partner. not a very romantic solution, but definitely a situation that favors the forgiver. you mentioned the financial aspects of a relationship, and cheating actually has basically 0 impact on that. i once sat in a psychology class having to write an argument about the phrase 'those who marry for money get all that they deserve' and my only critique on the statement was 'why are the words 'for money' in that sentence? those who marry get all that they deserve, it doesn't matter what your reasons are, if you marry purely for love, you're just as big a fool' maybe the love is gone, maybe they aren't a really big fan of their partner personally, but the financial aspects of the marriage mean their whole life is fairly easy as long as they don't separate, or in some cases, initiate separation. this can, again, be a net positive. sometimes, people are just punishing themselves or whatever by keeping a cheater, but a lot of the time, it's not so much forgiving the cheater for cheating as much as acknowledging that life is just better by keeping them, even though it will never be as good as it might have seemed. that might sound depressing, but i've seen it in action. i've seen someone leave a cheater, only to come back 4 years later because things just weren't working out, and life with a cheater is better than what it was without the cheater. easy decision to make from that perspective. typo's and stuff, at this point i'm done.

premises: when we see a happy person, we share a part of their joy. this is caused by the process of empathy, for which the anterior insular cortex is responsible. that is a region of the brain near the amygdala. seeing fellow humans happy caused them to be happy, therefore they began to be moral. initially, they carved flowers in cave walls, later they wrote proposals and tractates on parchments, and eventually philosophers such as aristotle formed the organized system of ethics. they have been taught this by their parents, learned that in school, came to that conclusion by talking with their peers etc they prevail everywhere around the world, and change is difficult and slow. aside from machiavelli, whose views only roughly correspond with modern day machiavellianism, ayn rand was one of the first philosophers who suggested egocentrism. that was only around 70 years ago. also, humans still take joy in the happiness of other humans. they are fond of the delight of their friends, lovers, parents etc they are motivated to make self sacrifices for the sake of other people. there's nothing wrong with 'second hand happiness'. if you love your wife and buy her flowers, she'll be happy. assuming you have an unimpaired amygdala, you will also be happy for her. that's how the brain works. i feel that what i'm about to say now might be superfluous, but i also anticipate that people will bring it up if i don't cover it immediately. wish your co worker good day, and he might volunteer to handle some of your assignments. however, sometimes initial rewards are more valuable than relationship enhancement. say your neighbor is looking for a thousand dollar bill and he can't find it. you find it and pocket it swiftly without him noticing. now, if you gave it to him, he'd most likely be grateful. he might cut your grass, invite you for lunch; but if you take the 1000 you will be rewarded by something far better, money. a moral person would return the money. an egocentric person would keep it. additionally, i would like to point out that in most cases, and this one, those who do something are the ones who have a higher duty to explain it. we shouldn't be ethical 'just because' or due to it being 'good'. amp; x200b;

making peace between faith and rationality? deities being more vague than ever? however i'm open to changing my view if anyone is able to relate to situation in my post.

conclusion: Fake porn such as "deepfakes" is not immoral
premises: you've probably heard of the new 'deepfake' technique for swapping faces in video or images by now, and the fact that it is often used to creating fake porn of celebrities etc. but i don't really think so. i think it is perfectly fine to make and even publicly post such media. i guess the reasons why i think so can be summed into three main points: 1. it's not real. it's fiction. it doesn't represent an actual event. there isn't really any meaningful difference between this and a bad photoshop, or a caricature drawing, or even fanfiction text. it just looks more real, but why does that really matter? no matter how real it looks, it isn't . it may look uncomfortable to some people to see what looks like themselves in vulgar scenes, but just because something is uncomfortable to look at to some, does not mean it is inherently immoral. 2. you don't own the image of your face. every day you willingly give it away by walking in public or posting selfies of yourself online. this is especially true for celebrities. it's almost their job to make their appearance as widely known as possible. and even if you don't, you're not entitled to 'own' illustrations of yourself like a copyrighted piece of art anyway, at least not by default. it's human nature for people to remember how other people look and picture them in their heads, even in thoughts such as sexual fantasies. and if that's okay then i don't understand why it's not okay to just copy these thoughts into a tangible format such as an illustration. 3. technology is ever improving, and faked imagery is only going to get more realistic and easy to produce. i'm sure last century there were people equally offended by faked porn that would to our eyes look ridiculously bad and unrealistic. fakes are here to stay, and we need to adapt our sense of morality to reflect this reality. i believe this will happen and such images will get normalized sooner or later either way, but i think it would be in everyone's interest to just get it over with and make it sooner rather than later.

conclusion: Websites should not have mandatory limitations on passwords.
premises: by forcing a password to be over 8 characters, they are eliminating all possible passwords that are less than 8 characters. by forcing a password to contain numbers and or special characters, they are eliminating all possible passwords that do not contain numbers and or special characters. most people use patterns when adding numbers and special characters to accounts. they replace certain letters with numbers sp chars, or they add the numbers sp chars to the end. when passwords are forced to be more complicated, or when websites force users to change their passwords often, the odds of users forgetting passwords will increase. as someone who has worked in it, i can say that the easiest way to guess a user's password is to read the stickynote stuck to the computer. people write down passwords when they can't remember them. it makes it very easy to gain access to their account; even easier than if they had a very common password such as 'letmein'. when users forget passwords often, websites employ methods such as attaching email addresses, phone numbers, social media accounts, and recovery questions to the account. this reduces overall security, because if any of those things i just mentioned are hacked, then a 'hacker' can easily gain access to the user's account without having to guess their password. for example, if i can see that their account recovery question is 'what was my mother's maiden name? ' , then that is almost certainly easier to guess than it would be to guess their password. the overall security is reduced. instead of forcing password restrictions, users should have the freedom to choose a password as 'strong' or as 'weak' as they wish. inform the users when they are making their account how strong their passwords are, and give recommendations. but at the end of the day, let the user choose whatever password they wish at their own discretion. cmv!
argument: Websites should not have mandatory limitations on passwords. : by forcing a password to be over 8 characters, they are eliminating all possible passwords that are less than 8 characters. by forcing a password to contain numbers and or special characters, they are eliminating all possible passwords that do not contain numbers and or special characters. most people use patterns when adding numbers and special characters to accounts. they replace certain letters with numbers sp chars, or they add the numbers sp chars to the end. when passwords are forced to be more complicated, or when websites force users to change their passwords often, the odds of users forgetting passwords will increase. as someone who has worked in it, i can say that the easiest way to guess a user's password is to read the stickynote stuck to the computer. people write down passwords when they can't remember them. it makes it very easy to gain access to their account; even easier than if they had a very common password such as 'letmein'. when users forget passwords often, websites employ methods such as attaching email addresses, phone numbers, social media accounts, and recovery questions to the account. this reduces overall security, because if any of those things i just mentioned are hacked, then a 'hacker' can easily gain access to the user's account without having to guess their password. for example, if i can see that their account recovery question is 'what was my mother's maiden name? ' , then that is almost certainly easier to guess than it would be to guess their password. the overall security is reduced. instead of forcing password restrictions, users should have the freedom to choose a password as 'strong' or as 'weak' as they wish. inform the users when they are making their account how strong their passwords are, and give recommendations. but at the end of the day, let the user choose whatever password they wish at their own discretion. cmv!
auto_conc: websites should not force you to make a password that includes numbers and special characters
gt: as someone who works in it, you should know the common methods for obtaining passwords. using brute force is one of the more common methods, and passwords with less characters are a lot easier to guess than with more. using 8 characters as a minimum with special characters and capital letters gives 95 8 possible passwords. that s over 6. 6 quadrillion possibilities. 6 with fifteen 0s . modern cpus can t crunch that many passwords in a reasonable amount of time. reducing the requirements makes it a lot easier to hack into. as for the physical methods, those are assuming that the hacker has access to the physical locations. in those cases there is usually some sort of physical security to the location to prevent it. not always but in that case, it doesn t matter how easy or complicated the password is. forgetting the password and using password recovery is always a method that can be breached. which is why more websites are using 2 factor authentication instead, where they send a text message instead of email. finally, it is not the website s responsibility to ensure that users keep their password stored or remembered. it s their responsibility to make sure that their website is secured, and provide a method for users to recover it. so enforcing higher security for passwords is the most they can do.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a good idea to force a password to be over 8 characters, but i think it is a bad idea to have a password that is 8 characters. if you want to make it easier to guess a user's password, you should make it harder for them to remember it.

conclusion: Diversity of beliefs and thoughts is way more important than diversity of identity
premises: it's a pretty simple one. few people complain about how the majority of young people and the media are liberal, and mostly circlejerk in echo chambers of opinions. now i will acknowledge sometimes identity automatically gives you a different viewpoint. for example, diversity matters when talking about islam, because a muslim can talk from experience. but i dont think having a muslim person in unrelated cases is worth anything just because they're muslim. in general, i'd rather have a board of 10 straight white males with all differing political stances and opinions than a board of black, white, men, women, and whatever else inbetween that all have leftist opinions. if that makes any sense. cmv.
argument: Diversity of beliefs and thoughts is way more important than diversity of identity : it's a pretty simple one. few people complain about how the majority of young people and the media are liberal, and mostly circlejerk in echo chambers of opinions. now i will acknowledge sometimes identity automatically gives you a different viewpoint. for example, diversity matters when talking about islam, because a muslim can talk from experience. but i dont think having a muslim person in unrelated cases is worth anything just because they're muslim. in general, i'd rather have a board of 10 straight white males with all differing political stances and opinions than a board of black, white, men, women, and whatever else inbetween that all have leftist opinions. if that makes any sense. cmv.
auto_conc: I think diversity of thought is more important than diversity of people.
gt: i think diversity of perspectives and expertise is the most important thing. thinking about it in terms of my work as a scientist, i've found a lot of value in working with people with diverse training. i work in one area of biology that intersects with a lot of other fields, and i'd rather tackle most projects with a team of smart people that includes a math major and a chemistry major than three biology majors. i've worked with people from a variety of demographic backgrounds and i think about them primarily in terms of what they're good at doing; their race and sexuality are irrelevant. however, politically, all of these people range from center left to far left. i have never worked with a conservative professionally, because they either don't want to go into my field or don't make the cut. there is no ideological litmus test that stops conservatives from becoming scientists. they're not being persecuted. they just don't make it. part of the issue is that conservatism in the modern american form holds some very stupid ideas that repel intelligent people who have a wide range of life experiences. for example, anyone who goes to college for several years is likely to have at least a few gay friends and want them to be happily married if they so choose. it's hard for someone who knows several gays as normal people who want to live normal lives to be afraid of them getting married or see it as a threat; that view can come only from unfamiliarity and or fervent belief in a self contradictory book of ancient fables. conservatism is also closely associated with several anti science views and policy actions, including rejecting evolution and denying the existence of anthropogenic climate change. people intelligent enough to become scientists are very unlikely to hold those conservative views. likewise, scientists are likely to have traveled quite a bit for research and to conferences, and to have lived in several different places; all of these things provide some exposure to other cultures and reduce the fear of other cultures, or of mixing of cultures, that's implicit in mainstream conservative positions on issues like immigration. if you were to insist that teams of scientists must have political views proportional to those of the country at large basically affirmative action for political views you'd have to reach for completely unqualified people to fill the conservative spots, and they'd have nothing to do but sit around picking their noses. conservatism in general rarely imbues somebody with ideas that make them valuable for any task, and certainly not in the way a different measure of diversity of knowledge such as college major does. there is certainly a role for center right conservatives, or at least for centrists, in opposing the occasional excesses of the far left. i would like to see a reasonable, good faith opposition to the far left as a moderating force in our politics. but conservatives who fit that mould are pretty rare.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'diversity.'i think you're conflating a group of muslims with a board of white, men, women, and whatever else inbetween that all have leftist opinions.
known_conc_attacks: diversity of beliefs and thoughts is not the same thing as diversity of identity.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'diversity of thought'. diversity of thought is more important than diversity of opinion.

conclusion: the story of Job teaches no valuable lessons, other than God is a jerk.
premises: by this i mean that the book doesn't contain any notable insights nor does it resolve any interesting theological questions, albeit i personally love it as a piece of absurdist fiction. worse than that, it seems to be undermining the very religion of whose holy text it belongs to. the book revolves a lot about theodicy; the problem of evil in the world. how can bad things happen to good people, and vice versa? the closest thing the book gives to an answer, is that we puny mortals can't grasp it. the israelites are taught time and again, that the reason they're getting slaughtered by fillistines or robbed and exiled is because they have turned away from god and sinned. they are led to believe, convinced by prophets send by god, that their actions have consequences corresponding to their sins. obviously when job suddenly gets hit by outrageous misfortune, his friends believe him to have committed some secret sin to cause it. we know however, that no such cause exists, and that god just wanted to prove a point to a buddy. god even scolds the friends for assuming that jobs misfortunes were caused by sin, like they have been repeatedly taught by him. all through the bible people are explicitly being punished or provided for according to their sins. by punishing job he is undermining the coherency of his followers, by denying them the belief that has kept them together through suffering and exile; that their suffering isn't pointless, and that it's all just and right. even if job gets richer in the end, how about his original sons and daughters who died horrible deaths for no reason? in the book satan raises the question of the possibility of selfless righteousness. some people are righteous whilst reaping no benefit whatsoever. the problem of unpunished evil goes completely unanswered. also, whether job even remains faithful is, in my opinion, up to debate. is it faith to maintain that god is injust and unfair? he repents at the end, but i would say satan won the bet here. furthermore, job is obviously right in saying that he is punished through no fault of his own, and therefore unfairly. he never explains how his action was fair, apparently because 'god works in mysterious ways' tm and no human could ever understand. except we can, it's right there, black on white, in the beginning: god punished job to prove a point to satan, and if people can't grasp the reasons for their suffering, they are probably either nonexisting or preposterous as they are in the case of job . basically the take away seems to be that sometimes, god is just a bully. phew, sorry about the rant, really needed to get this off my chest. anyways, i know that there are much more knowledgeable people than me in this sub, so i hope you can show me where i've completely missed the point which is probably the case and tell me why i'm wrong!

conclusion: I believe that it is both a waste of resources and unjustifiably selfish to have children in these times. I would go so far as to say its immoral.
premises: i got into an argument with someone over my opinion today, and they weren t able to articulate a convincing counter argument so i m wondering if one of you might be able to. my thinking is thus: we are living in an era of upheaval and political unrest all around the globe. we are just beginning to feel the effects of global warming and climate change, and in the years to come the effects will become even more dramatic. the planet is overpopulated. and it s been estimated that there are 153 million orphans around the world who need homes. if you simply must have a child, adopt one of the many who need a family. with all that said, what incentive is there for having a biological child? some people want to have a child that shares their dna, that looks like them, that will continue their lineage. and i m sorry, but in my book that s just plain old fashioned selfishness. why do you think you re so special? it s that kind of limited, self centered thinking that has gotten us to a crisis point as a planet. once all the orphans in the world have been adopted, and we ve turned back the clock on global warming and overpopulation, then maybe it ll be acceptable to procreate again. there was a point in human history where we needed to procreate so that the species would survive. now the opposite seems to be true we need to not procreate if we want to survive. i realize this is a very emotional subject for a lot of people. but really, why would you do that when you could adopt a child in need? for the sake of our planet and our species. can someone can come up with a different argument, that can withstand the scrutiny of logic?

conclusion: In no academic institution, including grade school, should there ever be such a thing as mandatory attendance. If a person can pass without ever having to show up to class, they should be allowed to do so.
premises: now, for starters, i'm not a big fan of our educational systems, but since i cannot offer a better practical alternative for the time being, let's speak in context of the current systems that are commonplace across most countries today. let's keep it simple, and we'll address any complexities as they arise in the comments. with regard our current standardized educational systems, the majority of schools and universities require that a student be present for a certain percentage of lectures in order to pass the course. imo, this is pure fucking bullshit; regardless of whether a student is in middle school, high school, under grad or post grad. plenty of the courses that i've been required to maintain an attendance rate of 85 of over the years have been a complete waste of time, and i could have been utilizing my time better doing countless other things. i just don't understand what the point is in having students attend the courses when they don't feel like doing so. interested in hearing different views on the matter.
argument: In no academic institution, including grade school, should there ever be such a thing as mandatory attendance. If a person can pass without ever having to show up to class, they should be allowed to do so. : now, for starters, i'm not a big fan of our educational systems, but since i cannot offer a better practical alternative for the time being, let's speak in context of the current systems that are commonplace across most countries today. let's keep it simple, and we'll address any complexities as they arise in the comments. with regard our current standardized educational systems, the majority of schools and universities require that a student be present for a certain percentage of lectures in order to pass the course. imo, this is pure fucking bullshit; regardless of whether a student is in middle school, high school, under grad or post grad. plenty of the courses that i've been required to maintain an attendance rate of 85 of over the years have been a complete waste of time, and i could have been utilizing my time better doing countless other things. i just don't understand what the point is in having students attend the courses when they don't feel like doing so. interested in hearing different views on the matter.
auto_conc: Attendance should not be a requirement to pass a course.
gt: well first it's important to know why some states created laws to begin with. in washington it is mandatory to attend school because of a bill called the becca bill. becca was a girl who was taken and killed. despite being gone for weeks, her school never informed anyone that she stopped showing up. the state decided that parents shouldn't be solely responsible for making sure kids are safe, so they created the bill. i work at a school and we must report when kids stop coming or regularly don't attend. usually, yes it's lack of motivation for various reasons, but sometimes it's family or community factors they can't control and letting the courts know about their absences can start the ball rolling in getting the student help. sometimes kids don't come because of abuse, neglect, drug addiction their own or parents . if you took away the legality to attend school, you'd no longer have this safety net.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of standardized education. it's not about the students, it's about the professors. if you're going to teach a class, you have to be present for it, and if you don't, you need to be there for it.
known_conc_attacks: i'm going to take a different approach. i'm a graduate student in a private school. i have to attend classes in order to pass. if i don't show up to class, i'm not going to be able to pass the course. i'll have to go to class on my own time.
auto_conc_attacks: if you don't want to pass the course, then don't do it. if you want to do it, don't be a dick.

gt: william nordhaus just earned the nobel prize in economics for his work on climate change. if you want to get deep into his work here is a link and some notes: the international target for climate change with a limit of 2 c appears to be infeasible with reasonably accessible technologies a target of 2 c is technically feasible but would require extreme virtually universal global policy measures moreover, notwithstanding what may be called the rhetoric of nations, there has been little progress in taking strong policy measures. for example, of the six largest countries or regions, only the eu has implemented national climate policies, and the policies of the eu today are very modest link 2 the study estimates that the scc is 31 per ton of co2 we show a calculation for constraining temperature to a 2 c limit in two cases: one with a hard cap of 2 c, and the second where that cap is for an average of 100 y rather than a single period. the sccs for the two limit cases are 184 and 107 per ton of co2 amp; x200b;nordhaus' research indicates that holding a 2 c target which is even higher than the new ipcc recommendation of 1. 5 or 2 would cost 184 per ton where the scc is only 31. this does not say that the cost is 0, but that it is overall more expensive to attempt to hold these stated numbers.

conclusion: X-Men is a bad and potentially dangerous metaphor for the LGBT struggle
premises: see, anyone can have lgbt experiences, and what is doing the harm is the categorization of people into neat boxes that you can use to oppress them. boxes that, at the end of the day, don't reflect the reality and the diversity of people's experiences. i think it's better to focus on the fact that the lines people draw in order to be able to oppress marginalized people are inherently blurry, and that you can't effectively separate people into those who you want to oppress and those who are immune. in the case of lgbt people, how strong should your attraction to the same sex be or to what extent should your gender identity not align with the one you were assigned at birth, in order to be excluded from the lgbt community? it's better to be inclusive than to try and accept the boxes that society puts us in. but being a mutant is different. you either are or aren't a mutant. there are no half ass powers. mutants and non mutants are different enough for a legitimate case to be made for separatism. this idea of separatism, that we're so different from non queer people that they're not allowed in our spaces, is something that i see gaining popularity these days, and i honestly feel like it could be dangerous, and it could exclude people who need our help most, young and questioning people who don't immediately adopt a queer identity as a lot of us do.

conclusion: If there is a universal gender wage gap, it is much smaller than reported.
premises: the commonly cited statistic is '77 on the man's dollar'. i don't think this is a fair evaluation, or evidence for widespread wage discrimination. there are tons of factors it doesn't account for. education, position, hours worked per week, willingness to demand a raise promotion, and willingness to relocate, to name a few. much of the above factors are choice. for example, out of the five best paying college majors, four are dominated by men. out of the five worst paying, four are dominated by women. is this discrimination? is there someone forcing women to choose poorly paying majors? no. a study by the american association for university women a clearly feminist organization found the wage gap to be not 23, but 6. 6 percent. it is entirely possible this is sexism. but it could be any number of other, unexplained reasons. despite what tumblr wants you to believe, there are differences between men and women. this doesn't mean that there aren't wage gaps in certain fields or that certain employers don't practice wage discrimination.

conclusion: A flaw with Reddit is that those who post comments early get the most attention.
premises: obviously this is not a die hard rule. often times people come into posts several hours late, but have a great comment, and end up getting enough votes to be seen. this results in them being seen more and, therefore, getting more upvotes simply for being seen. sure, you can see the best comments if you really look hard. i love reddit and really appreciate the vote based system it uses, but the fact that you can have an extremely relevant view or extremely relevant information for a post but that almost no one will ever see makes it flawed. i'm not saying i have a better solution. i did award one delta. i tried to respond to most people and will continue to do so if i see some interesting new view. comment.

conclusion: Souls don't exist

conclusion: People who say all politicians are the same/corrupt don't understand how corruption works, and are part of the problem.
premises: corruption, as any phenomenon occurring in a system governed by institutions, is a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. this enables a rabbit chase for 'the right' person, that will never really yield any results. even if we find an angel, it will ultimately be corrupted if the incentives are not right. instead of wasting energy on finding the right leader to whom a cult of personality is owed we should focus on designing systems where even devils are forced to act right. if having a functioning government was all about finding the right person, we would be doomed, as we can hardly tell what the real motivations and ideas of a given candidate are.

conclusion: It is plausible that most jobs in North America and Europe are mostly bullshit most of the time, (inspired in part by David Graeber's thesis in Bullshit Jobs).
premises: he's just the messenger. as graeber points out, 'when someone describes his job as pointless or worthless, he is necessarily operating within some sort of tacit theory of value: an idea of what would be a worthwhile occupation, and therefore what is not. the assumption in modern culture is that markets assess some kind of quasi objective value through pricing. if your labor isn't that valuable, for example, you will be paid less. hundreds of people reported to graeber that they get paid very well to do what appears to be wholly without value to society many of whom work in finance, for example . we can also point to countless activities that are widely accepted as valuable that are unremunerated, like helping neighbors plant flowers, household chores, etc. also, despite being absolutely critical roles for the functioning of society, many careers like education and waste management do not pay very much, and if left to the market alone may not even get done further suggesting there is something off about the market driven theory of value. so on the one hand, we have markets saying the value of a job is worth x gt; 0, while on the other hand we have the people working the jobs themselves saying they're not worth anything at all to anyone. that said, markets are just as susceptible to human error as human beings themselves. think about con artists swindling people out of money. do we say the con artist produced a value to the person swindled just because they convinced them to give them their money? what if some guru or company convinced millions of people to flush some massive portion of their earnings down the toilet every year? because those choices are fundamentally individual choices, they would clearly constitute market choices. but would it be any sign that the real value of those people's decisions? people can and do waste their money. the thing is, many of our primary motivators in life make it difficult to see this kind of waste even when it's right under our noses. in addition, politicians are highly motivated to endorse the expansion of jobs irrespective of whether they produce value. their motivations stem in one part from the lack of saturation of theories about what makes a good life, and in another part because, again, currently the only way to stave off starvation for the people they represent is to get them jobs at all costs bernie sanders' guaranteed jobs plan ring any bells? and just in case you think companies who thrive and flourish in the competitive marketplace are exempt from this problem, consider the fact that our entire economy goes through cycles of boom and bust, with massive hirings and layoffs that indicate that even this system, several times over the course of an average human lifetime, is subject to the same managerial and administrative bloat that government institutions are often rightly charged with. efficiencies take time to develop, perhaps even requiring countless iterations of boom and bust, and bullshit will thrive wherever these efficiencies fail to manifest. now this all might seem like a digression from my claim, but i think it's essential to have in mind for its analysis. there's nothing particularly fancy about the argument. garbage collectors, teachers, nurses, physicians, architects, construction workers: if they ceased to exist, we would be in real trouble. physicians, for example, may spend gt;50 of their day sitting through bureaucratic meetings, and or ticking boxes on endless forms that could be automated away by technology. major researchers report being forced to spend more time on grant proposals than actually performing research or teaching students. so change my view. feel free to use your own experiences. but don't forget i am just making a plausibility claim, and given my extremely flexible definition of bullshit, if you even agree with the simple claim that there's a lot of bullshit in human decision making behavior in the harry frankfurt sense of bullshit , then you might already be a priori on my side. have a good labor day.

auto_conc: I believe that school is a waste of students' time
gt: i'm a teacher and have been for 7 years. i've taught abroad, in a rich private school and at a large urban public high school. when i taught abroad my students came into my class and worked hard for the hour i saw them. we got through a ton of stuff. the jokes and off topic banter was minimal during class and this lead to much more work which is math in my class . i had 11th graders taking the ap calculus test and getting 4s and 5s. when i taught at a rich private school it was similar. i thought middle school and the kids were much younger and less serious, but they came to work. if they were out of line i'd contact the folks and get them in line. we got through algebra 1 quickly and effectively. in both instances i assigned minimal homework. 5 10mins 3 days a week. at my public high school there are seniors in algebra 1 alongside incredibly bright freshman. the fresh show up on time and do work but the class is often derailed by those seniors who stroll in late, take forever to get started, sarcastically respond to me and barely do shit. i wish i could get through everything in the class period allotted but the simple fact that we structure class like this and don't offer a tract for less academically skilled kids to veer off and achieve in a different i am left managing kids. this takes time. a lot of time. i'm good with classroom management and i actively engage my lowest performing kids so they can muster a good grade instead of a 12 or something equally poor. but it is time consuming and difficult to explain a concept to a reluctant 12 grader over the course of an hour when that same freshman learned it in 5 minutes. this means there's a lot of review, many different ways to express the same topic, hands on examples, activities to keep them off of their phones and on the work. i give homework for two reasons: 1. to get those kids that need help to do work independently so i can see what they need to work on. analysis. 2. to push those other kids that should work independently and move ahead.

conclusion: I don't see how morality can be objective
premises: it's abstract. unless you believe rational thoughts can appear without any humans present, it's subjective. the reason things like trees are objective is because if you were to kill every human, the tree would still be there. but you can't say the same for something that exists in head. so yeah, that's my argument. i'd prefer no theological attempts at changing my view god exists and his morals are objective because that'd completely shift the focus of the discussion, and i'm an apatheist.
argument: I don't see how morality can be objective : it's abstract. unless you believe rational thoughts can appear without any humans present, it's subjective. the reason things like trees are objective is because if you were to kill every human, the tree would still be there. but you can't say the same for something that exists in head. so yeah, that's my argument. i'd prefer no theological attempts at changing my view god exists and his morals are objective because that'd completely shift the focus of the discussion, and i'm an apatheist.
auto_conc: I don't believe in an all-knowing and all-seeing.
gt: i generally believe that morality is subjective for the most part, but i think it is possible to construct a non theological framework for objective morality. tell me if you disagree with my definition of morality, but i'm going to use one of the first ones i found with a quick search: a system of ideas of right and wrong conductthe first step is to decide on some goals, some purpose for having morality. this step is a bit subjective, but i think theoretically you could come up with a few baseline points that a large amount of people could agree with for example, we want a system of morality that minimizes suffering, while maximizing enjoyment and quality of life. all of those terms might have to be defined a bit better, but lets imagine we sit down with a bunch of people and decide on some metrics that we can agree on to determine quality of life, suffering, etc. at this point, i think i can believe that there is some objectively optimal morality that we could choose to adopt, which if we all followed would fit the criteria layed out in the previous step. without a god to deliver that morality to us, we might not ever discover it, and even less likely that everyone would choose to follow it, but it probably exists, independent of whether we know about it or not.

conclusion: James Cameron's Avatar is Underrated
premises: but by now the circlejerk about 'pocahontas in space' or 'fern gully in space' or 'dances with wolves in space' have come so far that i feel that this movie has gone around to being pretty dang underrated. let's knock that first big criticism right off the bat: yes. the plot is derivative. but to be honest, there are a lot of derivative movies out there, so i don't think that's as huge a knock against the movie as other people do. and honestly, the plot structure makes a lot of sense: you have a big crazy world you've developed, what's the best way to get the audience to appreciate it? take an audience proxy character and put them through a protracted fish out of water narrative. now on to the movie's good points firstly, it's one of the only movies, and especially one of the only not completely animated movies, to get a really really good result out of 3d. i've seen the movie 4 times since it came out in 2009: twice in theaters, and twice seeing the extended cut at home protip: the extended cut really does improve the plot quite a bit . and if it came back into theaters in 3d, i would watch the hell out of it in that format, and i'm not normally one to shell out extra for movies in 3d secondly, the movie is technically and visually very well executed outside of 3d: the creatures are all interesting and cool; the ecosystem is dramatic and visually stimulating, mixing tropical rainforest, influences from undersea structures, and karst style rock formations; the near future style human technology is all interesting and gives a good sense of purpose and feels used and lived in. the opening interstellar spaceship did the really cool semi plausible long distance spaceship design that the martian did, but years before that film. and to be honest, the cast is pretty excellent, especially in the roles they're given. stephen lang is awesome as a villainous version of r. lee ermey rip gunny . michelle rodriguez continues to do michelle rodriguez things, which imho is never bad, though it's always a little bit campy. sigourney weaver is good. sam worthington and zoe saldana are both pretty decent as well. so yeah, i think the 'derivative plot' circlejerk has gotten so strong that people ignore the good things about a movie that did a few things wrong and a lot of things right. i don't think it's a 10 10 movie, but it's a solid and entertaining film that stands up to rewatching.

gt: the best way that i ve been able to describe modern feminism is with the analogy of a race. normally, everyone begins at the same starting block, and when the gun goes off, everyone goes on a runnin. however, due to inequality, there are very few races in the world that have everyone on equal footing, if they could even be let in to start the race in the first place. in short, some racers don t even get to start at the start. in this specific case, we ll focus on women. the first wave of feminism brought western women up toward the starting line a whole bunch! the right to vote, divorce, etc, moved women s rights forward and gave them more of a fighting chance at equity. however, they still were not starting as far forward as men. next game advancements in attitudes toward female sexuality and reproductive freedom, equality in the workplace, each step bringing women a bit closer to the starting line. however, we are still not there. now, let s tackle modern examples that you ve given, like female representation in the media. this is, to some including me , a comparatively small step forward when it comes to getting to the starting line. however, it is still a step forward. think about it from the prospective of women in this race we see ourselves pushing closer and closer to the starting line, more and more toward equity. some people may see this, however, as their chance at the proverbial first place being threatened. technically, yeah. the more people there are in the game, the more likely someone else will win out. however, this is where i like to make things a bit bigger picture. yes, human nature is self preservation. we want the best for ourselves, and this is not always a bad instinct. however, it s entirely possible to want the best for yourself and want the best for others as well. that is why feminism has also fought to ensure that male rape victims are treated fairly in society and in law, that fathers have an equal chance in custody cases if they choose to pursue it, that men do not suffer from the same generalisations and stereotypes that harm women. i will not deny that every movement has its fringes that must be challenged when they make harmful statements, generalisations, and accusations. feminism is no different. however, it still holds the equity of sexes at its heart, and that means getting everyone to the same starting line. cassini.

auto_conc: Star Wars: The Force Awakens is not a good movie.
gt: i will disagree somewhat. pretty much all those issues can be papered over, or have reasonably sounding answers. the problem with the movie to me is more straightforward: it fails in its execution. i can believe rey is an amazingly powerful and competent individual but the movie failed to convince me that this makes sense. i can believe holdo might have had reasons to conceal information but the movie failed to convince me of this. i can believe leia could have jedi powers but the movie failed to set this up. i can believe luke could have had a moment of doubt instanity fear and considered killing ben for a second but the movie failed to give a proper reason. that, to me is what it all comes down to. the various problems are not necessarily inherently nonsensical or horrible. they could have worked if well done. the problem is that the movie failed at making them work. to give an example: the idea is that the movie has a theme of failure. but it never actually goes through with it. poe gets a lot of people killed and nothing happens really. nobody bashes his face in for killing their friends. nobody resists his mutiny because he's a maverick that already screwed up before. nobody demands him to be shot out of an airlock. he feels zero guilt at getting lots of people killed. holdo seems to feel zero guilt at how her handling of the situation resulted in a lot of deaths. the movie doesn't actually go through with what the actual results of those failures would be. if you're going to write a whole movie around failure, you have to actually do it, not chicken out instantly.

conclusion: Fact cannot possibly exist.
premises: all fact is based on repeatedly similar results from the same act. this is invalid in two ways. firstly, ad antiquitatum is the argument that you cannot predict the result based on past observation. if every time you have smacked a table with your fist it has made a loud noise, that does not necessarily mean it always will. 100 of all past observation is 0 of the conceptualised infinite possibilities. this applies to all instances of scientific observation of any kind. secondly, all past observation is based on individual human perception. nick bostrom argues that all perception has the capacity to be simulated. scientific recordings of temperature, physics, any instance of proposed scientific fact is refutable.
argument: Fact cannot possibly exist. : all fact is based on repeatedly similar results from the same act. this is invalid in two ways. firstly, ad antiquitatum is the argument that you cannot predict the result based on past observation. if every time you have smacked a table with your fist it has made a loud noise, that does not necessarily mean it always will. 100 of all past observation is 0 of the conceptualised infinite possibilities. this applies to all instances of scientific observation of any kind. secondly, all past observation is based on individual human perception. nick bostrom argues that all perception has the capacity to be simulated. scientific recordings of temperature, physics, any instance of proposed scientific fact is refutable.

gt: as many others have pointed out the ability to verify a fact is completely separate from whether something is in fact a fact. also, things that are vague enough and dealing with the past are facts. this is a 100 percent factual statement from my point:i currently believe that at some point in the past that i was working with the vim or on my ubuntu server. that is a fact even if i never did in fact play with vim since i am merely stating my current believe which can be verified at the particular moment, any change in the future would not reduce this statement to nonfact.

conclusion: Cultural Appropriation is largely misidentified, and should be addressed on a case-by-case basis
premises: some background: i'm a cis, white, liberal woman. this particular opinion i hold is one that tends to clash with the general belief systems of many of the communities and political sects that i consider myself a part of, and that's why i'm coming here to hopefully gain insight into aspects of this phenomenon that i, as a white person, may not realize or understand. i feel like an example scenario may be the best way to explain what i mean, so here we go: jenny is a 16 year old white girl. she lives and goes to school in an area that has a fairly equal population of black people and white people. she has seen black girls online and in school that wear box braids, and she thinks they're beautiful. she regularly compliments all kinds of women on all kinds of hairstyles that she thinks are pretty, and gets inspiration from them all the time. eventually, she decides to go get box braids for herself. she posts a picture on social media and some guy named richard comments 'so hawt! ! ' or something. a look back through richard's post history shows that a week ago he made a post disparaging natural hair hairstyles, calling them 'ghetto', 'trashy', 'ugly', what have you. as annoying sounding a term as it is, i truly do believe that 'cultural appreciation' is a genuine thing although i hate saying it because i feel like it has the same connotation as 'all lives matter' or some shit . anyway, my point here is that jenny loved a certain hairstyle, and acted out of nothing but admiration and respect. had she been the one to previously condemn such a hairstyle when worn by a black woman but gone on to decide that it was 'okay' if she did it, then she certainly would be guilty of ca. in this instance, the only person at fault is richard, who also didn't commit ca, but was absolutely a massively problematic bigot. regardless of whether jenny's hairstyle was what incited richard's hypocrisy, she is not the one responsible for his skewed stances or more accurately, the larger societal views that he represents in this situation . basically: there's no doubt that in many instances, society vilifies an aspect of a certain culture simply for the association with said culture, but then glorifies it when it presents itself among 'white culture'. this is absolutely problematic, but attacking well meaning individuals is the wrong way to deal with it.

gt: as a black woman i feel like the hairstyle conversation is distinct from other cultural appropriation in that, in addition to people not giving crwhere cris due and using it to be edgy, a big part of it is that most white people who have black hairstyles just don't look good with it tbh. our hair is different, so if you want to get the same look with straight hair you're going to have to modify the process. most white people don't bother to put that amount of work into it, and as a result their hair usually looks and sometimes is see: white people who don't wash their hair to get 'dreads' nasty. it hurts to see someone get praise for doing something you'd be mocked and scorned for, yeah, but the hairstyle itself is offensive is because their copy is ugly as hell and they're claiming it's the same as ours. and black women usually set aside full days to do our hair right and we have to do a hours of research before that too, so seeing someone who felt like they could half ass something we work so hard on and get similar results and then expect our praise for it is irritating on a visceral level.

'

gt: participating in party politics isn't necessarily about engaging in tribalism or group think, and it certainly doesn't mean agreeing with the party line on every single issue. there is far from consensus on many issues in either major us political party, even among elected officials. just look at the voting records of us representatives or senators, almost none of them vote along the 'party line' 100 of the time. parties aren't about dogma, they're organized coalitions of groups with often vastly different views that are willing to compromise with each other on certain issues to see change they want on other issues. the main reason most people choose to engage in party politics on one side or the other by which i mean registering with one party, voting in primaries, donating to candidates,favoring candidates of a specific party, etc. is because it's by far the most effective way to actually see meaningful change on issues they care about. voting in primaries or engaging in party activism can dramatically change the platform of that party on certain issues. donating to candidates or volunteering will help elect a candidate that aligns with you on issues you care most about. i'm not trying to say there aren't issues with political parties in this country, or that there isn't often a valid reason to not want to support either party. i'm just saying that, as a citizen, refusing to engage in the party system is robbing yourself to influence issues you care about. it is often easiest to enact change within a system than outside of it.

voice or slam a door to know mommy and daddy can't stand one another. and if you grow up in a family where the parental foundation is really a shaky facade, the kids will be raised feeling insecure about their family and their relationships. 4 one of you is likely to cheat on the other it's happened so much around me in the past few years it's sad, and that is one or even both spouses cheating. whether it gets discovered or not, it's happening a lot. if you cheat, you made that decision with free will. 5 very few people have what it takes to fix a marriage if you and your spouse have spent this last item is probably the biggest one that someone may be able to change my view on. what seems to happen, though, is that one or maybe even both parties in the marriage is unwilling and or incapable of doing what is necessary to fix a bad marriage.
argument: Divorce is not a Tragedy; a tragedy is staying in an unhappy marriage. : and i am not going to address marriages that contain abuse, drug use, or financial irresponsibility. i'm just referring to marriages that have become roommate situations at best, daily fights at worst. 1 you will not grow. it should be a place of mutual respect and support. but if you are in a marriage with a disconnected, unsupportive, nagging, etc. , spouse, any growth you make will be survival skills. 2 you will likely become depressed. people often assume that someone is lonely if they are alone, but i'd argue that sometimes the feeling of being alone when you are with someone is much worse. that feeling of knowing things shouldn't be this way, that you've tried and tried and you are still stuck and have no means of making the marriage work and just pass each day as co managers of shared life logistics is depressing as h ll. the inability to fix a marriage will make this worse, and while there are thousands upon thousands of counselors and books and classes and talks about fixing your marriage, in truth they rarely work. 3 you will have a negative impact on your kids there's so much to tackle here, so i'll just cover the most salient points. kids will learn what marriage looks like from you. some say that they don't fight in front of the kids, so it's not hurting them. well, kids pick up on the negative emotions in the room. you don't have to raise your voice or slam a door to know mommy and daddy can't stand one another. and if you grow up in a family where the parental foundation is really a shaky facade, the kids will be raised feeling insecure about their family and their relationships. 4 one of you is likely to cheat on the other it's happened so much around me in the past few years it's sad, and that is one or even both spouses cheating. whether it gets discovered or not, it's happening a lot. if you cheat, you made that decision with free will. 5 very few people have what it takes to fix a marriage if you and your spouse have spent years being unable to communicate and resolve your issues, if you have reached the point where you nitpick each other in front of your friends, etc. , i think the marriage is dead and can't be saved. this last item is probably the biggest one that someone may be able to change my view on. what seems to happen, though, is that one or maybe even both parties in the marriage is unwilling and or incapable of doing what is necessary to fix a bad marriage.
auto_conc: i believe that marriages that have become stale and uninteresting can never be saved.
gt: absolutely true. if you re not happy you re not living your life to the fullest, you re not making your partner happy you re not making your children happy. what s the point of staying in a situation that is making nobody happy. better to be alone and happy than together and miserable.

conclusion: The next James Bond must be non-white
premises: not for the sake of representation, but because the series has nowhere else to go. rations continued well past the war, the big changes in society were inward universal healthcare, declining heavy industry, pop cultural awakening, migration from former colonies changing the social makeup . the uk s power to project colonial strength by hard power pretty much ended with the suez crisis. a form of soft power to say: we re still here. the uk is not like this today. the empire as it stood has completely ended. the younger generation has no clue what this colonial outlook is like. the capital is one of the most ethnically diverse places in europe. brexit happened. the fantasy of the sophisticated colonial gentleman is a symbol with nothing to signify. while daniel craig salvaged the character from the cheesy nonsense of the later brosnan years, he s also showing his age, and his bond specialises in being a broken, shattered, deconstructed version of the sean connery ideal. after casino royale, not much about the character has been added beyond the eternal metatextual isn t it time you retired? that s why the new bond should add a totally different perspective. it shouldn t be like kingsmen a crass send up of the old bond style but something that acknowledges the shift to different, more fractured ideological conflicts and the post colonial age. the new bond shouldn t be a colonial tourist, but someone who can navigate apocalyptic ideologies nationalists, fascists, jihadists and complex identity politics with ease and understanding. the new bond shouldn t be casually waltzing into a cold war type super villain lair that has cold war fantasy weapons like space lasers, but uncovering networks of ideologically linked cells that work on makeshift means and exploit political conflicts. he shouldn t have all technology handed to him by q, but understand how the internet works as a field of conflict and be somewhat digitally savvy. most of all, he shouldn t be a fantasy figure from the late colonial age. he should be a product of that era s consequences. there s no better way to embody that than with an ethnic minority bond. it shows a globalised, not formally colonising uk. it imbues the character with an intrinsic understanding of navigating different worlds and cultures. it forces the filmmakers to not lazily retreat to retreads of past films. it makes bond going to exotic locations meaningful and difficult, because it can no longer be taken for granted that a colonial gentleman can just swan around the rest of the world like he owns the place. it raises the stakes of the character and the films to match the stakes that exist in our world today.

conclusion: It's stupid to join a High IQ Society like Mensa
premises: high iq societies are clubs that typically only allow members with a certain iq percentile. people who join these clubs typically do so to indicate that they're intelligent and to socialize with peers who are as intelligent. the reason i think it's stupid is mainly because i believe these people put way too much value into their iq. and iq score is typically a very narrow indicator of intelligence, excluding things like emotional intelligence, creativity and social skills. not to mention it's outdated, since the iq of the general population has been steadily growing, but the average is still set to 100. meaning that and iq of 140 is less impressive than it used to be. which brings me to my main point in that his members overestimate the value of iq, a lot of them probably take much pride over it because they lack other significant achievements in their lives.

conclusion: (Theoretical) physics is no longer beneficial and should be defunded
premises: in past eras, advanced physics helped humanity develop by explaining the world around us. it helped us understand orbits, advance our knowledge of how atoms function, leading to developments in many fields, and enable our technology to take advantage of more mechanics of the universe than before. however, recently the amount of useful results to come out of the physics field seems to have dwindled. now, most of what is produced seems to deal with highly conceptual research, such as string theory and quantum gravity. other avenues of research, such as particle physics research, produce information with little to no practical uses for humanity. the large hadron collider alone cost 4. 75 billion, and annually requiring approximately 1 billion to continue operation. although the collider was instrumental in proving the existence of the higgs boson, the particle has no uses. other experiments involve not investigating anything new at all, merely proving and re proving what we already know about relativity and its related research. instead of continuing to pour money into a field which has extremely limited benefits, i believe funding should be taken out of the physics field and used to solve real problems in the world. the money used to build the lhc could have been used for things like feeding the poor, fixing the education system, or advancing medicine. if the lhc's annual budget was taken away, there would be an extra 1 billion dollars every year dedicated to solving tangible real world problems.

conclusion: The left is more fascist than the right in America.

gt: as others have written here, your definition of fascism is not consistent with any of the vast historical or political science scholarship on fascism. indeed, it seems you quoted nearly the entire definition from dictionary. com except for the part about key parts about nationalism and racism. you simply cannot have a meaningful discussion of fascism without talking about nationalism and a racialized view of the nation. this is well summarized by kevin passmore in a short introduction to fascism: fascism is a set of ideologies and practices that seeks to place the nation, defined in exclusive biological, cultural, and or historical terms, above all other sources of loyalty , and to create a mobilized national community. fascist nationalism is reactionary in that it entails implacable hostility to socialism and feminism, for they are seen as prioritizing class or gender rather than nation. this is why fascism is a movement of the extreme right. fascism is also a movement of the radical right because the defeat of socialism and feminism and the creation of the mobilized nation are held to depend upon the advent to power of a new elite acting in the name of the people, headed by a charismatic leader, and embodied in a mass, militarized party. fascists are pushed towards conservatism by common hatred of socialism and feminism , but are prepared to override conservative interests family, property, religion, the universities, the civil service where the interests of the nation are considered to require it. fascist radicalism also derives from a desire to assuage discontent by accepting specific demands of the labour and women's movements, so long as these demands accord with the national priority. fascists seek to ensure the harmonization of workers' and women's interests with those of the nation by mobilizing them within special sections of the party and or within a corporate system. access to these organizations and to the benefits they confer networks terms of service, there is no censorship of the right wing. there is absolutely no evidence that mainstream right wing voices are silenced in america. in fact, they have their own loud speakers, like breitbart or fox news. none of this compares to the way that trump has delegitimized the media. in fact, his war on truth bears many resemblances to the fascist technique called 'the big lie. ' 3. i'm not really sure what work 'regiment' is doing in your definition, but this is the part that seems to least relevant to fascism. economic interventionism, the left most certainly is. but that does not make them any more or any less fascist than the right. amp; x200b;

conclusion: Infinity War was not that good.
premises: spoilers, obviously. also standard first time posting and on mobile disclaimers. at the time of writing, the movie has an 84 certified fresh rating on rotten tomatoes and the poll on r movies has a mean rating of 8. 81 i'd link it, but again, mobile . and despite wanting to love it, i came out of the movie largely disappointed. here are my complaints. 1. thanos is not a great villain. his rhetoric rings empty: the whole 'ultimate solution' schtick is never once challenged directly and never has an alternative solution proposed. sure he 'loves' his 'family,' but that's told to us, not shown, really. 2. the fights look good, but were ultimately nonsensical. strange's only use of the time stone ends up being pointless as he doesn't follow through unless that's part of the setup for how the avengers 'win' later in the follow up, which still rubs me the wrong way 3. in a 2 1 2 hour movie no one, with the very minor exception of vision, got any character development. i understand this is a consequence of the ambition of the project, but that's no excuse. and here's where i'm going to put a secondary super spoiler warning 4. literally erasing 50 of the cast was incredibly lazy. i understand this was an attempt to pare back the frankly unmanageable number of characters but it came off as an obvious plot device. having no rhyme or reason to who got dusted may have made plot sense but it's no coincidence that the characters lost were a. not the super main main characters ie tony and steve or anyone with whom they have unresolved plots ie black widow and b. were actors who likely had to be paid disproportionately to their screen time ie sam jackson, idris elba . the only outliers here to me seem to be starlord and strange. i have more minor complaints but this post is long and pretentious enough. cmv! i am admittedly a movie only person. that being said, i prefer to evaluate the experience in only that context.

gt: here's the official position of the dnc, as stated in the 2016 democratic platform preventing gun violence with 33,000 americans dying every year, democrats believe that we must finally take sensible action to address gun violence. while responsible gun ownership is part of the fabric of many communities, too many families in america have suffered from gun violence. we can respect the rights of responsible gun owners while keeping our communities safe. to build on the success of the lifesaving brady handgun violence prevention act, we will expand and strengthen background checks and close dangerous loopholes in our current laws; repeal the protection of lawful commerce in arms act plcaa to revoke the dangerous legal immunity protections gun makers and sellers now enjoy; and keep weapons of war such as assault weapons and large capacity ammunition magazines lcam's off our streets. we will fight back against attempts to make it harder for the bureau of alcohol, tobacco, firearms, and explosives to revoke federal licenses from law breaking gun dealers, and ensure guns do not fall into the hands of terrorists, intimate partner abusers, other violent criminals, and those with severe mental health issues. there is insufficient research on effective gun prevention policies, which is why the u. s. centers for disease control and prevention must have the resources it needs to study gun violence as a public health issue. what part of this troubles you enough to vote for someone from a different party? note that in these modern times, the 4th amendment is much more important than the 2nd amendment in securing our freedom from tyranny. however, i appreciate that some people are in situations where they need guns to ensure their personal security.

conclusion: Most recreational drugs should be legalised.
premises: the subject of drug usage can sometimes be a somewhat taboo subject. some people are very conservative about this and others are not. why? well when any society attempts to control the consumption of any substance by banning it, we get black markets. that is essentially all strict drug laws do, they create a black market. that black market fuels organised crime and demonises certain persons from society. my second reason, is that if you legalise certain drugs people are consuming anyway you remove the taboo of them seeking help if they become addicted. as it currently stands there is help for those who want to quit smoking tobacco or quit consuming alcohol. these drugs are arguably far worse than most other substances available on the black market. my last reason is i fully believe that a lot of people can take other substances responsibly, in the same way one consumes alcohol. not every user is an addict. i think we need to stop demonising people for wanting to let off some steam by taking a substance that allows them to make their lives that bit more bearable. i welcome any counter arguments here, in which may change my view.
argument: Most recreational drugs should be legalised. : the subject of drug usage can sometimes be a somewhat taboo subject. some people are very conservative about this and others are not. why? well when any society attempts to control the consumption of any substance by banning it, we get black markets. that is essentially all strict drug laws do, they create a black market. that black market fuels organised crime and demonises certain persons from society. my second reason, is that if you legalise certain drugs people are consuming anyway you remove the taboo of them seeking help if they become addicted. as it currently stands there is help for those who want to quit smoking tobacco or quit consuming alcohol. these drugs are arguably far worse than most other substances available on the black market. my last reason is i fully believe that a lot of people can take other substances responsibly, in the same way one consumes alcohol. not every user is an addict. i think we need to stop demonising people for wanting to let off some steam by taking a substance that allows them to make their lives that bit more bearable. i welcome any counter arguments here, in which may change my view.
auto_conc: I believe all drugs should be legalised.
gt: i would say yes, ideally most recreational substances would be legal, however, each place has different histories with recreational substances, different laws, different societal beliefs, that would significantly impact the way they would be received. in a significantly religious state, there may be more of a backlash, people may interpret the state supporting the legalisation as a move against the grain or the tenets of the major religion. a state with a significant drug problem, may abuse the legalisation of such substances and temporarily regress into a self indulgent binge, while states with less prominent social problems may be relatively unchanged by the move, with those that partake in recreational consumption of drugs no longer threatened hindered by the laws that previously restricted use and possession. really subjective, no one knows what will happen. while some countries have had notable success in the legalisation of some or all substances, in conjunction with controls against the production, acquisition and resale or substances, this is not necessarily the result other countries would experience. whatever countries decide to do is a risk. countries that permit more freedom in regards to all aspects of illicit substances are taking a significant risk. whether a given country is willing to take on such a risk is subject to so many variables that are beyond the bounds of discussion of this post.
masked_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that there is a difference between legal and illegal use of a substance. legal use of marijuana is a very different thing from illegal use. if you want to legalize marijuana, you need to legalize it for recreational use. that doesn't mean you can't legalize it, it just means that you have to legalize the use of it. it's not like you can legalize all drugs, it's just that you don't have to.
