auto_conc_attacks: i don't know about you, but there are a lot of people who are addicted to drugs, and some of them are quite addicted to them. there are also plenty of people that are completely addicted to heroin, cocaine, meth, heroin, crack, crack cocaine, etc. but they aren't addicted to those drugs. they're addicted to these drugs. i don't think it's a good idea to legalize all drugs, because it would lead to a massive increase in addiction.

conclusion: Of all the men (rightfully) accused in the wake #MeToo, Louis C.K. deserves a second chance.
premises: let me say at the outset that what louis c. k. did was wrong and morally reprehensible for a variety of reasons. this post is in no way a defense of what he did; it is, however, trying to put it into perspective of other forms of abuse. i understand this opinion is a unpopular one, but am truly looking for people to cmv in this post, and explain to me their viewpoints. i want an honest discussion about a very sensitive issue. i also want to say that i am a man, but my family has been affected by sexual abuse. at the end of the day, while i believe louis c. k. should be punished in the court of public opinion, i do not believe that punishment should include a lifetime ban from entertainment the same way i feel it should for people like kevin spacey, bill cosby, and harvey weinstein, for the following reasons: 1 degree of the accusations: i believe that 'bad things' have degrees. unwanted exposure and lewd questions are horrible and deserve consequences; but physically violating someone through physical contact is far worse. i don't believe it is fair to equate louis exposing himself to someone physically violating another person's own body, as was the case with cosby, spacey, and weinstein. i think that the physical violation of another person's body is one of the most vile acts human beings can do to another person, but that is not what louis c. k. did. of the 3 instances reported in the nyt article, none of them involved physical contact. there is one anecdote about louis possibly shoving a women into a bathroom , but as of now we don t know if this actually happened nor the circumstances involved. no woman has come forward to directly accuse louis of this. 2 a reasonable explanation: in his response to the ny times article, i am sympathetic to c. k. 's claims that he did not fully understand how much power he wielded over these individuals because of his celebrity. to his cr, in every one of these instances, c. k. did ask before committing these acts. these instances seemed to happen at the time when his career was first starting to really flourish. i take him for his word when he said he didn t understand how, in his newly found celebrity, asking wasn t really asking. that is in no way an excuse for what c. k. did because his behavior was still wildly inappropriate, but i am still somewhat sympathetic to his explanation, which leads into my third point 3 lack of predatory nature: louis c. k. made bad judgments, but his behavior does not seem predatory to me the same way cosby's, spacey's, and weinstein s were. he never threatened to ruin a woman's career for not allowing him to expose himself in front of them, and based on the information we currently have, it seems as if this behavior stopped at some point. now, it is alleged that c. k. s agent david becky may have made vague threats on louis' behalf to the women who accused him, but i don't think that is enough to put that blame on louis. it is possible becky was acting without c. k. s knowledge. furthermore, when the ny times article was published, i found louis c. k. 's response to be a no bs acknowledgement of both the accusations and the hurt he caused. i think we have to give c. k. crfor that. 5 a learning moment: undoubtedly, the importance of metoo is that it finally gives victims of sexual assault a voice. but perhaps also we should hear from truly contrite men who have behaved inappropriately in the past to understand their reasoning and learn from their thoughts and regrets. i don t believe we should give predatory monsters like cosby, spacey, and weinstein a voice to explain their actions. it may be too soon for c. k. to make a comeback , but i think some day he should be allowed to.

auto_conc: I don't believe Louis CK should be banned from entertainment forever.
gt: louis c. k. deserves a second chance once he's made peace with his victims, and those victims have given their blessing for louis c. k. to have a second chance. look at what dan harmon did: and his victim, megan ganz, accepted the apology: dan harmon deserves a second chance. once the same happens in the louis c. k. saga, he'll have deserved his second chance as well. when louis c. k. went on stage, unanounced, after a mere 9 month exile, he made a rape joke. i think a few more years of time out are justified. he clearly has a lot more to learn.

known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to understand that louis c. k. didn't ask before committing these acts. he did ask because he wanted to be seen as a good actor. he didn't want to be considered a bad actor.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think that louis c. k. should be punished in the same way that kevin spacey, bill cosby, and harvey weinstein should be banned from entertainment. i think that it's fair to equate the physical violation of another person's own body to a lifetime ban from entertainment, as was the case with cosby and spacey.

conclusion: The movie/films/games/software industries lost the fight against piracy. Instead of trying to find ways to make it harder to pirate stuff, they should introduce a tax/fee on electronical devices, that will go to content creators - and make the content then "free".
premises: honestly i am not too sure how big of a problem piracy is nowadays, but i still see companies governments coming up with new ideas to combat it. like filtering uploading content, forcing gamers to stay online at all times, etc. despite those efforts a quick glance on piratebay shows us: pretty much everything is available. that money then gets distributed to public tv radio but also private stations proportionally to the consumption of those stations. along those lines this 'content fee' would also get introduced, just that its not a yearly fee, but a device bound tax fee. like the share microsoft gets when someone buys a laptop on which windows 10 is installed. when buying a new iphone you would pay number totally made up 10 of the price additionally, but then you gain access to any distribution service, that provides licensed products. spotify, netflix, photoshop, website of your local garage band, download harry potter e book. com, watch hollywood movies. com, you name it. some independent, publicly funded group then controls the numbers and then distributes the money gained from the tax or fee proportionally. i think netflix and co have proved that money isnt the main issue when pirating, but convenience. so if you have everything available when buying a laptop, then no one would even bother to seed a torrent simply because there is no demand. and by buying a laptop you also payed for the series you will be watching. also netflix proved that its possible to prevent dns or proxy servers from working. this means its possible to block non participating countries out. content that is free anyway, like youtube videos would get nothing of this fee, since ads would still be a thing. also merchandising of any form is left out. this means if you want a blu ray you also still pay for the physical copy. i am aware that bots would be a problem and that implementation would be tricky, but those seem manageable details if the industries and authorities really commit to this idea. maybe not, no clue about the technical difficulties would love to hear some stances about this idea. so, what did i miss and why is this idea shitty?

conclusion: If I am an oppressor, it is in my interest to remain one.
premises: i am a straight white male. for many, this means that i am not only in a position of privilege in relation to several other groups, but also that i hurt the interests of those groups by unconsciously exhibiting certain views and behaviors. for the sake of the argument, lets grant all of that. let's also assume that everyone is equal, regardless of sex, genetic background etc. and the only source of outcome variation is historical injustice and various structures and ideologies that support oppression. even if all of the above is true, there is no reason for me to actively seek to empower groups that i don't belong to. power is relative, so every bit of power that women, immigrants, minorities etc. gain, i lose. in fact, all of these groups have a proven record of actively trying to take my power away. not only that, but some of them openly declare so just enter the term 'white men' into google news. women's rights are a good example of this. 99. 93 of humans are born biologically male or female. that makes me concerned, because again, i want to be in a position of power, no matter what. perhaps men have oppressed women, that doesn't concern me. what concerns me is that we're not oppressing them now. even if we, just for the sake of the argument, assume that women are superior to men in some significant way, it would only make oppressing them all the more necessary. based on this reasoning, i support all political action that hurts the groups that i don't belong to. this has led me to having political positions that would be seen as extremely disagreeable by the absolute majority of westerners at least that's what i'm assuming . and i should probably emphasize here that this is not an ideological choice. more power is better than less no matter what. even if i was benevolent, i would still rather be benevolent from a position of power. now here you might say 'hey, this power stuff is weird, who thinks like that? ' and perhaps you're right. however, i have only about 80 years to live and i intend to extract maximum utility out of those 80 years. every millimeter matters. that's not to say that i go out there and engage in some kind of violent activism i still gain much more by just working towards my goals on my own. still, that doesn't stop me from feeling a little bit of joy every time i hear a complaint about women's reproductive rights or how the police in the us apparently hate black people.

groups, but also that i hurt the interests of those groups by unconsciously exhibiting certain views and behaviors. for the sake of the argument, lets grant all of that. let's also assume that everyone is equal, regardless of sex, genetic background etc. and the only source of outcome variation is historical injustice and various structures and ideologies that support oppression. even if all of the above is true, there is no reason for me to actively seek to empower groups that i don't belong to. power is relative, so every bit of power that women, immigrants, minorities etc. gain, i lose. in fact, all of these groups have a proven record of actively trying to take my power away. not only that, but some of them openly declare so just enter the term 'white men' into google news. women's rights are a good example of this. 99. 93 of humans are born biologically male or female. that makes me concerned, because again, i want to be in a position of power, no matter what. perhaps men have oppressed women, that doesn't concern me. what concerns me is that we're not oppressing them now. even if we, just for the sake of the argument, assume that women are superior to men in some significant way, it would only make oppressing them all the more necessary. based on this reasoning, i support all political action that hurts the groups that i don't belong to. this has led me to having political positions that would be seen as extremely disagreeable by the absolute majority of westerners at least that's what i'm assuming . and i should probably emphasize here that this is not an ideological choice. more power is better than less no matter what. even if i was benevolent, i would still rather be benevolent from a position of power. now here you might say 'hey, this power stuff is weird, who thinks like that? ' and perhaps you're right. however, i have only about 80 years to live and i intend to extract maximum utility out of those 80 years. every millimeter matters. that's not to say that i go out there and engage in some kind of violent activism i still gain much more by just working towards my goals on my own. still, that doesn't stop me from feeling a little bit of joy every time i hear a complaint about women's reproductive rights or how the police in the us apparently hate black people.
auto_conc: i'm a straight white male, and i don't feel bad about that.

gt: do you consider diseases to be only those things with tangible representations in the real world? meaning something which can be isolated and examined on some level, like a bacteria or a virus or a patch of cancerous skin cells or a particular brain formation even the absence of something like a depressed person missing their correct balance of neurotransmitters? because a great deal of mental disorders psychopathologies would not meet that criteria. there are many debilitating conditions which have no physical representation in reality. it would be nice if you could take someone with ocd, put them in an mri, and say, 'you see this bump right here? that's your ocd. ' unfortunately most conditions like this don't work that way. also . . . if someone is regularly taking a substance drugs for a long time, then goes off that substance, the nerve dendrites which normally recieve the neurotransmitters produced by taking the drug can actually start to grow seeking more of the drug. imagine the dendrites are like garage doors that drugs use to park their cars. if you deprive those garage doors of cars, they will start making more garage doors in the hopes of enticing more cars to park in them. it's a literal ramping up of the craving for more drugs that someone who has not been taking a lot of drugs wont feel. and when the next time there's a big flood of cars, well look at all these nice new garages to house them all.

conclusion: Instead of teaching youth to "not judge" we should be teaching them *how* to judge with kindness, mercy, logic, and fairness.
premises: let me start by explaining what i mean when i say judge in this context. i am a father of a 5 year old girl and as anyone who's spent a lot of time with babies and young children, i want to help guide her through life and give her the tools to interpret the world around her. when we see a child behaving very poorly in public there are times when i choose to speak with her about what's happening. at the onset of this moment, when we are going to voice our thoughts about the behavior of others, whether it's my daughter and i, you by yourself in your head, or anyone in really any circumstance, we are entering a judgmental space by it's literal definition. any way to frame, or speak about some else's actions requires judgments to be made. our society has made the word 'judgmental' have strong negative connotations, and i believe people are uncomfortable with using others as teaching opportunities for fear of being 'judgmental' here's an example of what i'm talking about. daughter and i see a child screaming in the market, jumping up and down creating a massive scene, hitting their parent ect i'll ask my daughter 'why do you think they're being so terrible' i insert the view i'm teaching, that the behavior is terrible, so judgment is made but begin a dialogue. normally she'll say 'they're mad' or something like that, and we'll talk about things that make us mad, what might have this other child mad, i'll say something like 'i get mad, you get mad, everyone get's mad sometimes, it's ok to be mad but that's not how we act when we're mad right? ' i believe we should be creating a template for judgment to exist, where it's where the person's identity isn't attacked, but their behavior and actions content of their character are understood and discussed. the person who could change my view would do so by showing me how this style of parenting causes more harm than good and i shouldn't have a conversation with my daughter making judgments about the misbehaving child. after reading lots of really amazing responses i have learned a few things. firstly that framing things this way with some of the specific language could be bad for my daughter because when she steps out of line, she inserts herself as the 'terrible' child, or that she is doing 'terrible things', which may be true by whatever definition we have for terrible, it can damage self esteem and doesn't promote healthy learning. 2ndly there is a problem with syntax and semantics with the term judgment, and while none of those arguments swayed me, they are still very much relevant. lastly, it's friday afternoon, and i'm going home. be well.

auto_conc: it's ok to be judgmental when raising a child
gt: while teaching kids, i get lots of utterances like 'this song is shit', and that's very tiring after a while. on the other hand, i respect everyone's freedom of speech and thinking. so i try teaching them to distinguish between blatant judgements and justified opinions. the latter ones 'i find this song shitty because' using the lines of argumentation that you described are acceptable for all. the former only for professionals in a given area.

conclusion: Voting isn't actually productive or necessary
premises: however, i just can't shake the feeling that it doesn't really do anything. my singular vote doesn't mean anything. the electoral college and what my state is held by matters. like, i'm in texas so my vote for beto isn't gonna matter because my district is so gerrymandered that my liberal section of the state is partioned out with smaller, conservative west texas. i have voted democrat in every past election and it doesn't matter because the state is held by republicans. i'm not here to debate republican vs democrat by the way. cmv.
argument: Voting isn't actually productive or necessary : however, i just can't shake the feeling that it doesn't really do anything. my singular vote doesn't mean anything. the electoral college and what my state is held by matters. like, i'm in texas so my vote for beto isn't gonna matter because my district is so gerrymandered that my liberal section of the state is partioned out with smaller, conservative west texas. i have voted democrat in every past election and it doesn't matter because the state is held by republicans. i'm not here to debate republican vs democrat by the way. cmv.
auto_conc: i don't think my vote matters in this election.
gt: everyone seems to feel this way when it comes to election day but we so easily lose track of the link to the the actions behaviors of these officials throughout the rest of the term. lets assume you are super cynical about politics and you feel that all politicians are cheats and liars. they are still elected officials and and the end of the day have to pay lip service to the voters and make it look like they care about their constituents. that need to put on the air of caring for the people will influence the way that they are writing legislation and making deals which actually benefits people. maybe it is a 80 greed 20 social benefit kind of deal but imagine if those same people did not have to care about voters then it would be 100 greed all the time in which case you lose that 20 benefit. knowing that people are at least generally watching does have an effect. so even with a cynical view of the government it is super important to maintain voting as a healthy institution. the less that people care about politics the less that politicians will care about people and the most direct avenue for expressing care about politics is voting. if you are less cynical about politics then the rate of return for the value of voting only goes up.
masked_conc_attacks: the electoral college doesn't mean anything to you. it just means that your vote doesn't matter.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're forgetting that the electoral college is a system of checks and balances. it's a system that allows you to vote for whoever you want, even if you don't want to vote at all. it doesn't mean that you can't vote, it just means that you have to vote. if you want to be a productive citizen, then vote.

conclusion: The mainstream (US) Left and Right are both equally divisive.
premises: i would first note that i'm specifically talking about the mainstream dialogue, not the radicals on either end of the perspective. also, i am apolitical partially due to my career and do not favor either party or vote. i've noticed as several recent pieces of literature state the right wing is the source of political division as if it is axiomatic. i'm not talking about low hanging fruit types huffpo, salon, etc but legitimate academic works including straight talk on trade by dani rodrik president of political economy harvard and a world in disarray by richard haass president of the council on foreign relations . that said, historically, it's very clear that the right has been the perpetrator of division on race and every other aspect. but lately, it sure seems that the liberal wing is resorting to identity politics on the level of the early 20th century. there is division between urban and rural that smells like the pre holodomor period in ukraine, white supremacy living in the ether like alleged schemes of jewry in the northern european plain, and an attack on religious attitudes that resembles the ideas that led up to the early 1900's christian armenian genocide in turkey. i'm not positing that we're on the brink of a catastrophe. it can't be quantified necessarily, but it's definitely there: paul ryan has identified as such. change my view. i would also add that from my experience on reddit only been here for about a month , the left wing is brutal to the point of downvoting moderate ideas that exist in law today, or the current state of the economy, such as employment figures. as someone who pays attention to political polling, i'm aware that this isn't the state of the country at large.

conclusion: I believe nudity should not be illegal
premises: so there's some nuance to my beliefs here. if someone is caught outside without clothing then there shouldn't be any sort of repercussions or fines that affect them for being naked outdoors. in public transportation, like on buses or trains, we shouldn't have public nudity because of the issue of transference of germs between people because of contact on the seats. this change would be primarily for two purposes: first 1 to get rid of the laws and fines that are placed on people for being naked. given certain circumstances these sorts of laws can be detrimental towards people, and punishes them for simply being in their most natural state. and 2 to allow people the freedom to express their bodies publicly how they wish to without fear of punishment by the law. simple rules like 'no shirts, no shoes, no service' would still be applicable towards those facilities that choose to enact them. for those who don't know, in spain nudity is legal minus a few regions like in barcelona. this doesn't mean that public nudity is acceptable everywhere, there's a lot of places where nudity is gonna be looked down on, such as in the middle of a town. but it's still legalized and the country itself has a lot of options for interested people like nudists. last thing to cover is probably going to be religious and moral beliefs that are going to possibly be affected by this. to which my best argument that i can come up with is the rule of freedom of expression. in the united states at least, this is part of one of the biggest rights we have: freedom of speech. i don't think we should be limiting our expression by enacting certain laws with how we present our bodies, even if that presentation means no clothing at all. so there's my case, let's see yours. i'd love for you guys to tear into it! let's discuss this topic.

conclusion: Defining sexuality as "attraction to sex" is an unhelpful way for people to label themselves: it should instead be "attraction to gender".
premises: small background: argued this point in another post, but the discussion was pretty cancerous and got nowhere, so i won't bother linking it; but feel free to look it up in my post history if interested the big comments, basically . i am very interested in legitimate counter arguments, so i posted this here. words have definitions, and are used to describe the world in useful ways. definitions cannot be proven wrong because they are axiomatic: they change overtime when a new definition for word x is better , not when the old definition is 'wrong'. this is not a good argument, as i see it. it's the rhetorical equivalent of 'it's wrong because it's not right', when the debate isn't about right or wrong, but more vs less useful, and definitions are never estabilished fact they change along time, locale, context, even between dictionaries . also: reminder that gender is, in pragmatic terms, gender identity expression, independent from sex. and for those unaware, 'trans woman' means male to female transgender, vice versa for trans men. just to avoid potential confusion. onto the real point: why is my definition more useful? as you can probably deduce from the title, the proposed 'change' has a lot to do with trans people. let's take a cis male attracted to cis and trans women. under the old definition, he is bisexual. however, why should he ever label himself as such? since he doesn't like men, cis or trans, he is not interested in showing availability to them: by labeling himself as bisexual, he is opening himself to that dating market, which he does not want to do. trans women generally view themselves as women, so they wouldn't show more interest towards a man who showed availability to other men; that is irrelevant to her. let's take another example: a cis male attracted to only cis women, 'straight' on the old definition: the change makes absolutely no difference. a potential counterargument is that he doesn't want to be open to dating trans women, but he can reject them, just as he would any other woman he doesn't like. an obvious counter argument to this counter argument, is that under the old definition, i could similarly say he is opening himself to trans men like buck angel someone a straight man is most likely not attracted to, so the argument is self defeating. deltas to whoever makes me rethink anything about this

conclusion: The USA is too litigious and strict with law, and it negatively impacts a lot of us.
premises: from invention creation on patents to multi million dollar lawsuits against medical companies, it seems to me that those who want to change our nation, often for the better, have to worry an unreasonable amount about the legal implications of their desires. from wanting to cure people the best you can, or in a way more similar to eastern medicine, to wanting to improve technology it seems there is often a law that restricts or regulates a person's ability to really get as far as they otherwise could. secondly i believe the desire to go to court over so many things creates an amount of hostility and fear in others. it limits many of our amendments, because you can sue someone over nearly anything we become afraid to say and do things we have every right to do. yet, the better lawyer often wins, not the actual person in the right, or in the wrong. i'm not saying we should dump lawyers as a profession, or litigation as a means of correcting a wrong. i am saying that billboard signs suggesting you take something to court is over the top, and measures should be taken to make this society more responsible and interactive. certainly some good arguments for having our court system and litigation as a means of compensation, protection, etc still searching for the point that would make america seem balanced in this aspect, though. u oneshomeisonescastle has brought up a very good point that there is no real way to go about changing how things are, i offer nothing in the way of 'fixing' the issue i bring up, and because of my general lack of experience on the topic, any fixes i'd suggest would likely break the system more i. e. people would have less access to legal services when it would be much better if they need them i don't entirely concede my original point, but somewhat digress there's nothing better i can offer.

conclusion: Marrying younger is a great option. (Not child brides but 19-early twenties, at least finish high school first!)
premises: my wife f25 and i m27 got married young. i was 21 and she was 19. i didn t have any engrained habits that needed to be reconciled with another person. i don t have a certain way that i load the dishwasher, budget my money, fold towels, soap preference, side of the bed i sleep on, etc. small things aren t an issue because we both came up with them together. 2. we developed as adults together so we formed to complement each other. i often joke that we are a one hermaphroditic blog with one mind because we have similar stances on issues. we don t have irreconcilable differences because we didn t have any engrained stances. no rvsd debates in on our house! i also always had someone to call me out on my youthful bullshit still do! 3. being married doesn t mean that i can t developer as healthy a individual. we have separate hobbies interests, viewpoints and tastes. there are plenty of things we can do separately. 4. also, i don t have the fomo fear of missing out about sowing my wild oats because i have an automatic sex buddy! 5. it s a better financial situation for broke young kids. now i m finishing up engineering degree and i have a sugar mama ; we also got tax breaks from an early age. there are more write offs for both being students at some point and there s a tax break for being married. there are many more minute points but the main ones are 1, 2 and 5. i think couples who get married young have a greater potential to do great.

auto_conc: i think getting married young is a good thing.
gt: aged 20 to 30 is arguably one of the most transformative times in ones life. yes, people can and do get and stay married during this time, but the risk factor is high because of this reason. the ideals and goals one has at 20 is almost always a very far stretch from where the ones arrives at 30 with, and because of that, binding your life with another person is not exactly the wisest thing to do. im not saying it can't work, i'm just saying it typically doesn't work and this is the main reason. marriage stands a better chance once both parties have moved through this period of growth. for some, they can grow together and find they want the same things out of life, but the reality is that most do not. i speak as someone who started dating my husband at 20, married at 26 and were still happily married at 35. so i know what's possible, but for every couple like us, there's 5 others who had the opposite experience.

conclusion: The US needs a Constitutional Convention
premises: hopefully this isn't too common a topic on cmv; the last post to put it this way was 2 years ago and more recent ones were more narrowly defined and are nearly a year old themselves . it had a great run it's the oldest constitution in continuous use, but most modern constitutions are written to be updated more frequently and actually are. ours is only really updated by supreme court decisions, with only 2 amendments being ratified in the last 50 years one of which was first proposed in 1789! til . the founders could not have imagined the world we live in today or its challenges, and the document is written as such. flawed solutions like the electoral college were created to solve problems of the 18th century that are irrelevant in the 21st. the founding fathers saw tyrannical government as the biggest threats to the rights of individuals, and wrote the constitution to protect those rights. that was logical in their day, but that is not the threat that those of us in modern democracies face. tyrannical companies taking from an article that's currently on the front page are the primary threat to individual rights and freedoms, and our government and constitution is not equipped to deal with that threat. i'm sure i'll get into more specific critiques in the comments, but that buildup of history and precedent makes justice incredibly difficult to come by in many instances and needs revision. if you haven't, i'd urge you to read the text. it takes like 20 minutes for the main text; probably 40 60 with amendments and is available everywhere. one of the main arguments that will likely be raised that will not change my view is the political will difficulty argument. i know it would be hard or impossible to make happen, especially given current politics.

conclusion: A joint account with a percentage-of-income (with a few other considerations) is the best way to split money
premises: i know this can have a lot of exceptions. please don't make your arguments about pointing out 2 or 3 exceptions that are technically true. i'll list a few to save the trouble: a person with reckless spending or addiction gambling issues should not have this split. significant inheritances should not necessarily have this split the extremely rich or extremely poor should not necessarily have this split massive debts massive differences in work time lots of other exceptions but for most people, i think this split is the best method. money has an economic value. if you compare the salary of a strategic consulting manager and a veterinarian assistant, you're going to get 200k versus 40k or something crazy. but in a relationship, i don't think economic value should necessarily be considered, unless the difference in income is so vast that one person's income is literally chump change i. e. 500k vs 30k . in a relationship, especially that of a marriage, the 'most important value' is time and effort of the individual. person1 makes 80k after taxes; person2 makes 40k. person1 would input 40k into their joint account, while person2 inputs 20k. as a result, in real money, person1 is providing more. person2 is also providing 50 . caveat. please read this caveat. let's say for example i make 100k and my partner makes 20k. i put in 50k and keep 50k while she puts in 10k and keeps 10k. unfortunately, that means that i get to live it up and have a pretty damn good life whereas she has to keep both savings and expenses under 800 per month. so why this view? 1. 2. provides freedom to both people and rewards high earners in exchange for providing more this allows both parties to win. 3. this makes their life much more difficult and makes them less capable of affording more. 4. gifts are more meaningful in a fully shared money situation, gifts are important but also become difficult to justify. makes for a difficult situation. 5. use your own money. no problem! want to buy a ps4? no need to ask me, go for it! want to go out and treat 10 people out to drinks? go for it! not my money, not my problem. again this is basically the freedom argument. caveats i know there are exceptions to this rule. i'll try to list out as many as i can. and yes some of this repeats from the beginning of the post but i thought mentioning it twice makes it more likely for everyone to see it. here's a real life example. i make 80k and my girlfriend makes 30k post taxes. but neither of us works harder than the other. she makes 30k because she chose a career that's important for the world, but pays very very little. if we do a 75 75 split, then i end up keeping 20k per year. she gets 7. 5k. maximum retirement contribution is 5. 5k. so now i have 14. 5k left and she only has 2k. 2k for a whole year is nothing. she can barely afford anything for herself. i keep 20k, she gets 15k. now it's more even, now it's fairer. cmv

1. 2. provides freedom to both people and rewards high earners in exchange for providing more this allows both parties to win. 3. this makes their life much more difficult and makes them less capable of affording more. 4. gifts are more meaningful in a fully shared money situation, gifts are important but also become difficult to justify. makes for a difficult situation. 5. use your own money. no problem! want to buy a ps4? no need to ask me, go for it! want to go out and treat 10 people out to drinks? go for it! not my money, not my problem. again this is basically the freedom argument. caveats i know there are exceptions to this rule. i'll try to list out as many as i can. and yes some of this repeats from the beginning of the post but i thought mentioning it twice makes it more likely for everyone to see it. here's a real life example. i make 80k and my girlfriend makes 30k post taxes. but neither of us works harder than the other. she makes 30k because she chose a career that's important for the world, but pays very very little. if we do a 75 75 split, then i end up keeping 20k per year. she gets 7. 5k. maximum retirement contribution is 5. 5k. so now i have 14. 5k left and she only has 2k. 2k for a whole year is nothing. she can barely afford anything for herself. i keep 20k, she gets 15k. now it's more even, now it's fairer. cmv
auto_conc: i think the most sensible split of money in a relationship or any relationship is: "you get what you deserve, she gets what she can afford."
gt: while i haven't personally dealt with large scale financing with a long term partner, i have been on many multi day dates or trips with friends that involved some amount of covering who paid for what, or people paying up front for rooms and getting paid back by the group later, or whatever. what i noticed was that there were two very distinct philosophies regarding payment. some people wanted extremely equitable payments, keeping track of most all expenses and the relative amount owed by most everybody. they would be very upset if they felt transactions were 'unfair', or if people failed to remember even minor exchanges who went on a donut run in the morning, or w e . another group of people, while obviously not willing to cover everything for people, would basically just take things as they went and expect all the little expenses to even out over time. if they noticed a trend e. g. they're paying for every donut run , they'd bring it up and ask somebody else to cover, but not try to figure out how much anybody 'owed'. to this group of people, not only did they not need to have everything turn out 100 equitably all the time, it was actually deeply unpleasant to deal with the sort of exact tallying and scorekeeping and reminders that were part of keeping things equitable. to use an analogy, it's the difference between the people who keep track of whose turn it is to buy a round at the bar, versus the people who figure that rounds at the bar will even out in the long term. relationships are no doubt the same way. some people might really want things to be equitable and to figure out exactly how much is appropriate to spend and who pays for what from the get go. if that's what works for you, more power to you. but plenty of people don't want that, and in fact find that sort of tallying to be a tremendous and unnecessary burden when a combination of trust not caring about exact quantities spent works out well enough.

conclusion: Alpha dog theory is not a myth
premises: watch this video to get a basic understanding of this discussion amp; x200b; here is my brief response: 1. there's a reason for dominant and recessive traits in our dna. genetic traits develop as we evolve to survive in our specific ecosystem. superior traits in male adults physical strength, endurance, intelligence, skin tone, etc attract females they can't help but be attracted, they're coded this way because they have a higher chance of survival in that specific part of the earth. he chooses the equally genetically desirable female. 2. regarding aggressive behavior, adam misrepresents the traits of the dominant male. the meek rule the earth. listen to the world's most powerful people speak. the last thing they are is aggressive because it displays a weakness in their ability to control their own emotions. being kind also actually takes more balls than being an asshole, simply because we are socially conditioned to think 'asshole she will let me fuck her', and if you go against the grain to be a man of honor, you will encounter resistance, but reap huge rewards as your character is revealed. change my view!

gt: your premises correct me if i m misrepresenting you :1 some traits in men are more preferable2 these preferable traits are genetic3 women s desire for these traits is also geneticto take each point in turn:1 no contest, if your talking in generalities2 some preferable traits are also environmental being born into a wealthy family and learned knowing how to cook 3 if we only wanted things for genetic reasons, women would idealize the same sorts of men over every time period. similarly, what kind of women men prefer changes in the 1700s, it was full figured women, in the 1970s it was narrow waisted women. if sexual desire is hardwired, it wouldn t be malleable. that it changes overtime suggests it s at least partially a software thing, as opposed to a hardware thing. evolutionary psychology is interesting, but it sometimes borders pseudoscience when it makes causal claims. usually, evolutionary psychology presents a theory that explains human behavior however, unless a theory is tested, it is just a hypothesis, a hunch. moreover, as this hypothesis does not explain all the facts, such as why our conception of the ideal man changes over time and culture, it s not even that good a hypothesis.

conclusion: I would have a happier, more fulfilled life if I didn't have to work.
premises: this belief dives into many parts of my life so i'll go through each. to me, working makes us slaves. people are forced to get jobs just to survive. everyday feels like a fight for my life. i feel as though if people were told that they could have food, water, a house, car and education for free, then we would have no worries to just do what we wanted to do with our lives. personally, if i could just spend my days carving wood, writing a book, or anything leisurely by myself, i would do it. don't confuse that sentence with 'i want to make a business out of those things i love' because i don't. if someone told me i could carve wood as my job, i'd be upset because then it loses the leisure. that once leisurely activity then becomes a means of my survival, the root of my fight or flight response, my anxiety and i don't want that. it's become clear that many are focusing on the 'needing some work for fulfillment' and the 'liesure leading to depression' answers. so i feel the need to expand my post to include that i'm more referring to working to survive. generally, i'm a busy body but working to survive is awful. maybe the cmv is actually 'the need for money survival prevents me from living a fulfilling life'. some have confused my desire to live a life without a need for survival as a desire to have anyone else help me survive and in that you'd be wrong. a stress free life for every person without a need for them to survive. ideally currently unrealistic , people just would survive. i don't know how i'm sure we're hundreds of years away from this solution and it would take more than just me to figure it out but it's beside the point. some believe that i think that things are just going to appear but throughout, i've only referenced resources necessary for survival. just a world where your basic needs are met. that doesn't mean tv, or movies, or anything that you don't absolutely need. those other things are wants not needs. so if you wanted something, of course you'd work for it. but if you needed something, that's different.

conclusion: It's unethical to accuse someone of sexual assault after 4 decades
premises: a great example of this rush to judgement is chris hardwick, who was actually removed from his show at amc based on allegations from his ex girlfriend chloe dykstra. so now we have a woman coming forward nearly 40 years later to accuse a supreme court nominee of groping her while in high school. aside from the fact that the timing makes her political motivations interesting and aside from the fact that her story does seem credible and aside from the fact that she apparently isn't willing to testify about it which is perhaps the worst part amp; x200b; there is a reason most criminal charges have a statute of limitations. for someone in brett kavanaugh's position, how could he reasonably be expected to defend the allegations in a meaningful way, in a way where he can clear his name with certainty? where were you on this day 36 years ago? who were you with? do you have an alibi? there can be no physical evidence collected or pictures taken, or detailed police reports of the events. the accuracy of of the statements of potential witnesses of an incident evidence shows eyewitness testimony isn't as accurate as we thought, and it gets worse over time. christine ford doesn't even know for sure when the assault took place, but she thinks it was 1982. amp; x200b;

conclusion: Poe Dameron was not simply just wrong for questioning Admiral Holdo and taking action, nor was he the "true villain" of TLJ.
premises: i think i maybe should've made this 'cmv: holdo should have done something to inspire all members of the resistance to trust in her and not come up with a plan of their own especially considering poe's history . ' poe obviously made some serious mistakes previously, but i believe that in regards to the chase and their plans, he and holdo were both right and wrong in some respects. i recently had a discussion with someone where they told me that they thought that he should have just trusted her and done as he was told, that all in the military should always follow their orders without question though i'm not trying to open another rabbit hole with that , and that the scene was meant to illustrate how men need to just shut up and listen to women. she may have had a plan and it may have worked and by that one could argue that she was right; i see this as a parallel to the jedi at large. i believe this ties in with luke's saying the jedi need to end and all of that to illustrate how even if one group may be in some way right, if they can't effectively communicate why they're right or something else to get people to trust in it enough to actually implement it, it's not going to succeed or produce the desired change or outcome regardless. like how much anakin was preached to about the evils of the dark side but was never communicated the realities of it well enough to successfully instill in him what it would take to get him to have not gone down that path. holdo failed as a leader by failing to instill the faith in her needed for her plan to work successfully. it's 100 fair for her to not have wanted to divulge specific details in an effort to safeguard the plan, but given what she thought of poe as a person i think it's completely fair to say that she definitely should have at least simply told him that she did have a plan and that she wasn't just going to let them all die without even trying to do anything, which is what she led them to believe was happening. she didn't even have a look of confidence when saying what she said to the crew, again that could have been intentional in an effort to keep the plan secret, but she should have said something more to, at least, poe. what good is a leader who knows exactly how to fix all our problems if they aren't actually a leader and can't get people to actually do the things to make those changes happen? poe was faced with a situation where he was basically told that they were just going to fly til they ran out of fuel and the enemies caught up and killed them, without even trying to do anything about it. he was given, so far as i perceived, no reason to support this order other than the fact that she was of superior rank. he made the call in his mind that since they were just going to let them all die that he would at least come up with a plan to try and do something about it, a plan which a black guy and an asian woman both also supported and helped to come up with but no one seems to talk about the black guy or asian woman who also didn't follow holdo and supported taking action on their own . this whole thing seems to be getting reduced to being about sex, or more specifically, the evils of white males and the patriarchy, and the fact that a black guy and asian woman also opposed holdo doesn't fit in with that notion very well. the other person also said how if he just would have followed his superior's order how the plan would have worked perfectly. one could, perhaps fairly, say that this wouldn't even be a factor or a point for me to make if he had followed orders, but i can also, i believe fairly, say that if finn and rose had followed orders and gotten the right person at the casino instead of deciding that they could make due with the option that presented itself as opposed to the one they were ordered to find that then poe's plan would have worked. really, both plans could have actually simultaneously worked. if finn and rose had gotten the right person and managed to covertly board the enemy ship and disable their shields, anyone not necessary for the fight could have escaped in the landing pods and just a few could have stayed back to try and destroy the enemy ship; in which case they would again already be facing death and if the battle started going south then they could have still simply flew lightspeed through it as holdo did on her own. i may be wrong but i think it's also fair to speculate that it would have taken fewer people in the ship for the battle than the number that died in the pods in the failed escape attempt. the last jedi, to me, was about how much more complicated these things are than any of us generally like to contend with. about the problems with the mindset of 'i'm right so you just need to shut up and do what i say because i'm right. ' they may damn well be right but that is certainly not an effective way to act because it will not inspire people to come to follow you. we must demand more of our leaders and we must be more sympathetic to and have more empathy for those we view as being in opposition to us, if not out of care for them out of care for actually advancing your own correctness instead of just ranting about how smart you are and how dumb everyone else is and how the world would be so much better if we just listened to you continuously because no matter how much you rant it doesn't cause the change you wish to see. yoda told luke that the best thing he may have to offer as a teaching are his mistakes, and from that he tells leia that no one is ever really gone. they can't give up on kylo, ben is still there. luke can't try to kill his nephew because of a dream he had and we can't declare people to be evil and delete them from our lives because they voted for trump. if we actually are so much smarter and want the world to be better then we need to be better and we need to do more and we need to care and work not just within the frame of how we feel things should be people should just follow orders and consider and work also based on how things actually are at the present moment consider your feeling that this person is wreckless and in your mind simply sexist and realize that they will probably not follow you if you don't do something more to get them to, regardless of whether that's something you should have to do or not . that is not, however, to say that we shouldn't also work to move things in the direction of how they should be. tldr some are acting like it's just an issue of sexism and i think that's an almost comically absurd i say almost because it's too troubling to really be funny for me, i thought the movie made such a beautiful statement that seeing it so severely oversimplified and misperceived damn near makes me sick oversimplification at best and to a degree just plain wrong.

conclusion: Casual dating (and casual sex) is inherently dehumanizing
premises: for instance, if you date someone just to make your ex jealous, you're clearly using and dehumanizing your partner. that example's pretty clearly wrong, but there are lots more that seem pretty innocent at first: if you're just dating around to find out what you like, aren't you just treating the other person as a means to an end? if you're dating someone casually because you just went through a tough breakup and feel like you deserve something light and fun, aren't you using that person as a substitute for a feeling? if you pick someone you wouldn't ordinarily date because you're sick of being single, are they just an emotional crutch? if you date someone in school you know will be moving away in a couple of years, are they anything more than a placeholder for a person? if you feel sorry for your nice single friend and go out with them to boost their self esteem, are you treating them as you would want to be treated? it seems to me that in each of these cases, you'd be guilty of using your partner. i can't think of any. a good rule of thumb might be: if your partner asks, 'why did you decide to go out with me? ' and you're reluctant to tell them the real reason, you're probably using them and you should probably break up with them. response 1: 'as long as it's between consenting adults, there's nothing wrong with it and we shouldn't judge them too harshly. ' consent is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for an action to be ethical. that is, for a relationship to be ethical, it must at a minimum be consensual, but it takes more than that. it must also be genuinely good in the long term for all parties involved. for instance, it wouldn't be ethical for two completely incompatible people to date each other just because they're both terrified of being alone, even if they both consent to it. they could even hurt others if they have children. response 2: 'as long as you're upfront about your motives, you're in the clear. ' few people are willing to be so upfront, precisely because they're aware of how much it makes them sound like a sociopath. 'i had a bad breakup and i'm just looking for a rebound. you cool with that? ' few people say that sort of thing upfront. and if you are upfront, sure, it may lessen your burden of guilt, but that doesn't mean you should be doing it in the first place. if you sell someone placebo drugs, and you tell them upfront, 'hey these drugs probably won't do a damn thing. i'm just trying to make a cheap buck. ' and they buy them anyway, sure, that's better than lying to them about it. but isn't it even better not to sell placebo drugs at all? similarly, if someone's just a rebound for you, it's better if you tell them that upfront rather than make them think they're special, but isn't it better still not to use someone that way in the first place? besides, our motives are often obscure even to ourselves. we may not realize someone was a rebound until the relationship is over. if you're not really, truly excited about someone after a few dates, then what are you still doing with them? response 3: sex is no big deal. it's just our messed up society that puts such an unhealthy emphasis on it. our society probably does have an unhealthy attitude toward sex. but sex is a big deal, and it's not just another activity like skiing. otherwise, we can't explain why forced sex is a special kind of crime. here's what i mean. rape is a serious crime, one that can potentially cause serious psychological damage. likewise, it's a serious crime for an adult to have sex with a child. part of the reason is that they can't meaningfully consent to sex. but why is meaningful consent necessary in this case? young children can't meaningfully consent to getting their hair cut or being taken skiing, either, but that's no crime. rape and sex with children are evil because it's a particularly heinous type of violation, perhaps a violation of something that should be sacred. it's not just an activity that our society places too much emphasis on. sex is intimate in a way that can cause lasting psychological damage if forced upon someone. presumably this is because sex is so deeply rooted in our biology that we can't help but have certain psychological reactions to it. sex does something to you, and you can't necessarily help it no matter how enlightened you are. or even if you can completely separate sex from all the messy emotions, you can't know if your casual partner is capable of doing the same, because you don't know them well. if sex is special, perhaps even sacred, we're playing with fire if we act as if it's no big deal. we risk hurting ourselves and others psychologically, even if it's all perfectly consensual. addendum: there's some part of me that still feels like i'm being ridiculous and unrealistic about my approach to dating, but my conscience won't be clear unless i can see why. or if i'm not being ridiculous, then at least i'll feel more confident about refusing to date anyone for any reason who doesn't meet my possibly unrealistic standards. i can't seem to settle this on my own, so i would appreciate some outside perspective and wisdom.

conclusion: Card games like Magic The Gathering are not gambling
premises: you generally know what you are going to get for your money using mtg as the example, you're going to get 15 cards, with a rare, 3 uncommons, and the rest commons. sometimes you get a foil card, sometimes a mythic rare, but it's always the same number of cards. these cards ostensibly all have the same value they can all be used to play the game they are for, and it's up to you, the player, to determine which cards warrant a place in your deck. the game's producer makes no claim about which cards are more valuable deciding which cards work better in your deck is a core part of the gameplay, and the producer would not want to break that by telling you which ones are better. any secondary market for the cards should not be taken into account. how is it the company's responsibility that other people might be willing to pay you money for what you got in your card pack? if you are opening a box of lucky charms, and i say i am willing to pay you a quarter for every unicorn marshmallow you give me, does that mean general mills is now engaging in gambling? even if dozens of websites spring up for the purpose of buying and selling lucky charms marshmallows, general mills is still no more responsible for the market value of any given marshmallow than it is now. sight unseen auctions are legal, and i see no reason to prevent them from being so. i think this same logic extends to digital card games like hearthstone, and even to loot boxes themselves, but i'll leave that for another post.

auto_conc: general mills is no more responsible for the market value of any given card than it is now.
gt: gambling can be defined as either 'play games of chance for money; bet. ' or 'take risky action in the hope of a desired result. ' . cracking packs of magic cards fits both of these criteria. by your logic, scratch cards would also not be gambling. you are buying a product without fully knowing what it contains, likely not to make your money back, but with the possibility for a large pay off. packs of magic cards are obviously a lot lower risk as you always get something and a lot lower reward unless you are cracking alpha beta , but it is still present.

conclusion: People who say all politicians are the same/corrupt don't understand how corruption works, and are part of the problem.
premises: corruption, as any phenomenon occurring in a system governed by institutions, is a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. this enables a rabbit chase for 'the right' person, that will never really yield any results. even if we find an angel, it will ultimately be corrupted if the incentives are not right. instead of wasting energy on finding the right leader to whom a cult of personality is owed we should focus on designing systems where even devils are forced to act right. if having a functioning government was all about finding the right person, we would be doomed, as we can hardly tell what the real motivations and ideas of a given candidate are.

conclusion: Too many people go to college in the US.
premises: tl;dr: i believe that the obsession with telling everyone to 'get an education' is misguided and has been incredibly harmful to our society. close to 70 amp; 37; of graduating high school students are now attending college of some sort directly after graduation. this has had a number of unfortunate results: 1. when 70 amp; 37; of the population excluding high school dropouts wants to go on to higher education, it means that there will be a mathematical guarantee that a significant amount of individuals with below average academic skills, intelligence and education will be attending. the result is that schools either must admit students that they know can't handle the workload or reduce the academic rigor in order to accommodate less capable students. 2. employers can no longer use a bachelors degree as a meaningful discriminator because they are way too common. when having a bachelors degree in a field not directly related to your job i. e. non stem was less common, an employer could infer that whoever had it was at least of an above average intelligence and academic ability, even if they didn't go to an elite educational institution. essentially saying, 'even though an english degree isn't really directly related to this job, this person still must be reasonably capable to have gotten a degree at all. ' now that degrees are handed out left and right, this is not longer useful. it is also very damaging to capable people who didn't get a degree and has forced people to take on more debt to attend graduate school or accept lower salaries in order to be competitive. 3. someone with 40th percentile intelligence is not going to be able to complete a degree in organic chemistry or mechanical engineering, so the result is they study largely useless degrees, wasting their time and money learning stuff they will never use on any job. while i certainly believe that having academics in a society has value, there is a limit of how many history and psychology degrees can be given out and still have marginal value to society. spending 4 years of your life and going deep into debt had better improve your employment prospects, and i really don't believe it does for most people of average to below average ability. go into a retail store or restaurant in a major city and odds are that multiple non management employees will have degrees. 20 years ago, this would have been unheard of. 4. it kill innovation and entrepreneurship. because so many young people come out of school with a ton of debt and no real skills even if you have a more useful degree , it kills entrepreneurship. someone of middling intelligence who has a ba in psychology isn't going to be able to start any business that they couldn't have out of high school. they certainly won't be as capable of starting a business as someone who spent those 4 years in trade school and or an apprenticeship learning how to do a real world skill. even if they have the ability, being saddled with debt means that they are less willing to take the risks required to be an entrepreneur. this is all well and good, but for something that costs as much as it does, it just doesn't make sense for the majority of people.

gt: there is a little bit of history here. after the vietnam war, many servicemembers came home to a response that ranged from embarrassment to disgust. even those who 'supported' vietnam vets often focused on very negative aspects and by extension characterized all vietnam vets as broken. i'm old enough to have had a lot of older friends who were vietnam vets, and served in the military directly after. the resentment was widespread. so some of the reversal has been, like all reversals, overdone. instead of just appreciating the sacrifice, many people decided to go all the way to revering the military and veterans. however, doing this often causes a similar harm because they still treat the veteran as separate and possibly broken. add to this the fact that many politicians have learned to use veterans as props. the current administration is the worst, but everyone does it some. once again, props are often separated, given almost magical status, then mistrusted, resented, and ignored in the end. i guess this probably won't change your view. but it's something that society hasn't gotten right yet, and i think it is important.

gt: one of the big issues with soccer is that there is such a high premium on scoring opportunities. it isn't uncommon for a game to only have 1 or 2 goals, and those goals coming on only a handful more scoring opportunities. with the premium on goals 1 goal can easily be deciding, particularly if the leading team adopts an all out defense strategy , the incentive to try and draw penalties either free kicks or penalty shots which can be scoring opportunities without any additional effort by the kicking team is massive. the best way for soccer to deal with this would be to reduce the benefit of flopping. that might mean taking steps to increase scoring so that 1 goal won't necessarily be deciding. that might mean reducing the benefit of free kicks e. g. you can dribble out with possession, but not organize a set piece . that might mean moving back the penalty kick so it isn't nearly as valuable in it's own right.

conclusion: College coding classes should be more focused on mobile & web app development.
premises: so i just graduated with my computer science degree back in april and after reflecting on what i learned in my coding classes, it seems like we are working with antiquated technology. as an example, i wouldn't consider my algorithms or theory of computation courses as 'coding classes,' because while some code was done, it was largely more theoretical stuff. my java and python classes however were just all about learning those languages. we dipped into php and sql in my databases class but that's about it. the first time i ever did a web app was when i learned . net myself working on my senior project. every other code class besides sysadmin if that counts never really touched on any networking topics. so what we learned through school for the most part was how to make an offline desktop app. you code something in java, you run a . jar file, and you're good to go, no coverage of rest api usage or anything. in reality, this isn't too relevant anymore. people don't use desktop apps in large quantities anymore, bar video games. the average person probably uses: chrome firefox, discord, steam, itunes spotify, and maybe 3 other programs of their choice a couple adobe products, maybe a few ides, etc. . mobile apps have largely replaced the usefulness of desktop apps. if you want a budget tracker for example, you'll likely just do it on your phone so you can punch in numbers whenever you need to. if there's a desktop app that isn't too fitting for mobile, typically it works better as a web app so people don't have to download specific software. of course i listed some desktop apps above that are still relevant and still useful, but they are much lower in popularity compared to mobile or web apps since they are typically less portable on a pc or require downloads and setup. and especially with every app being connected to the internet nowadays it seems downright outdated that we don't even so much as cover simpler web connectivity things like rest apis in these coding classes. i couldn't tell you how to integrate an api into a java application, and i used it for several years throughout highschool and college. cmv.

restore us to sanity. 3. made a decision to turn our will and our lives over to the care of god as we understoodhim. 4. made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves. 5. admitted to god, to ourselves, and to another human being the exact nature of our wrongs. 6. were entirely ready to have god remove all these defects of character. 7. humbly asked him to remove our shortcomings. 8. made a list of all persons we had harmed and became willing to make amends to them all. 9. made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others. 10. continued to take a personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted it. 11. sought through prayer and mation to improve our conscious contact with god as we understood him, praying only conclusion: Laissez Faire is the ideal Governmental/Societal Structure
premises: as morality cannot be imposed, and the smart, or selfish, or rich will always have advantage any system, however vetted, will produce unintended consequences. the more complex the regulation or system, the harder it is to evaluate the success. welfare, government oversight, banking and industry regulation, healthcare and similar policies inevitably fail to produce better results than the self correcting selfish incentives of competition. for example: the recent fiduciary rule attempted to standardize compensation for advisory services on asset management. this was meant to be a more strict policy compared to a disclosure based, potentially conflicted, model in which suitability was the standard. the problem which was attempted to be addressed was: broker has fund a and b which are both suitable, but picks a for revenue purposes. the solution was, fund a and b must pay the same. simply put . the reality was that the industry broadly increased fees holistically, to maintain revenue levels but collect it another way. average fees went up. in the chaos of the administration change, the standard was ultimately struck down. it seems to me, that ultimately, people learn from experience, and in the learning process even systemically, many problems self correct from individual incentive. a social darwinism of behavior, as evolution has shown us the impact of selective competitive advantage with iteration, why can that not apply also to society? us spending on welfare is comparatively high compared to international spending on a proportional decrease in standardized poverty levels can t vote on my phone directly, but a 2012 study was referenced on wikipedia s welfare page . my view could change with appropriate statistical evidence. it seems most of the research on these concepts are highly partisan, and the results are hard to take at face value. to be honest my current view is how i was educated. i would appreciate a differing, well supported viewpoint.

us spending on welfare is comparatively high compared to international spending on a proportional decrease in standardized poverty levels can t vote on my phone directly, but a 2012 study was referenced on wikipedia s welfare page . my view could change with appropriate statistical evidence. it seems most of the research on these concepts are highly partisan, and the results are hard to take at face value. to be honest my current view is how i was educated. i would appreciate a differing, well supported viewpoint.

conclusion: There is nothing wrong with the encouraging/ reinforcment of masculinity.
premises: i often see people criticizing phrases such as 'man up! ,' 'be a man! ,' etc, and claiming these are bad for young people men and women to hear. historically and biologically, men have been and are more combative than women so if a woman needs to be combative to accomplish something, i see no problem is saying 'be a man. ' this also applies to other traits such as independence. as an aside, some may argue that ideas of masculinity and femininity are purely socially construed and that people only act certain ways because of societal influence. i wholeheartedly disagree masculine and feminine traits largely have to do with the presence of sex hormones acting on the nervous system. so the idea that phrases like 'be a man' need to go away because it's keeping together a negative social construct are unfounded. if anything is unclear, i will be happy to elaborate on any ideas in the comments.

gt: would you agree that generally human beings can do things that are irrational and potentially harmful? masculinity and i would argue femininity as well are both sets of human behaviours that can be good or bad. and in some circumstances are definitely bad, you don't want people acting independently in a surgical operation, you want people working together in a very strict fashion. this is a conclusion that came about from comparing surgeries where people worked independently with ones where people used set checklists and protocols to coordinate, and finding that the latter had lower levels of mistakes made. i guess my main point is that masculinity is a good tool for when you need to be competitive or combative, but those situations are occasional for most people, and outside of them masculinity needs to be controlled. it's something that needs to work for you, not the other way around.

' quickly looking around the internet it seems like many arguments against this are pulling some logically fallacious reasoning saying something along the lines of, 'it's ridiculous to say illegal aliens aren't in the jurisdiction of the u. s. , obviously we can arrest them and charge them with crimes, so they are in our jurisdictio t. for example, the atlantic article s. in this view, schuck and smith misread the historical material ' it then also links an article in which it uses the argument about jurisdiction i talked about abo s. i would really appreciate some better argued materi l. the aforementioned atlantic article also links 'the citizenship clause: a legislative history' ? twitter impression true amp;httpsredir 1 amp;article 1607 amp;context aulr , which i am trying to go through; it's just a bit long amp; x20

gt: the cornell law 'article' linked is actually the full text of the supreme court's opinion. it's a fascinating read, rich in historical context and i thank you for sharing it as it shines a light on the question that news stories fail to adequately capture. here's the money paragraph from the opinion:the real object of the fourteenth amendment of the constitution, in qualifying the words, 'all persons born in the united states' by the addition 'and subject to the jurisdiction thereof,' would appear to have been to exclude, by the fewest and fittest words besides children of members of the indian tribes, standing in a peculiar relation to the national government, unknown to the common law , the two classes of cases children born of alien enemies in hostile occupation and children of diplomatic representatives of a foreign state both of which, as has already been shown, by the law of england and by our own law from the time of the first settlement of the english colonies in america, had been recognized exceptions to the fundamental rule of citizenship by birth within the country. so there it is, the supreme court, explaining after painstaking review of the law and history of the matter their conclusion that the phrase 'subject to the jurisdiction thereof' refers to three exceptions:1. members of certain indians tribes2. children of alien enemies in hostile occupation; and3. children of diplomatic representatives of a foreign state. that's it. the holding of the case is really that straightforward. if you are born in the u. s. and fall outside of these three exceptions, you are a citizen.

gt: culture is not the only aspect to heritage, genes are very much involved. for example, i'm predominantly scottish but i have everything from native american to german to dutch to english in my makeup. it is perfectly accurate for me to say that i'm scottish even though i and four generations of my scottish ancestry was born in the us. it's not only accurate but medically important: certain racial genetics can offer clues to herary disorders such as tay sachs and sickle cell anemia. if i tell you i'm scottish, i'm being factual and honest, even if i was born in the us. genetically, that is what makes up most of my heritage and its incredibly relevant. if i told you i was culturally scottish, however, that'd be a big fat lie. i'm culturally american, even if i do know what my family tartans look like and want to try haggis.

conclusion: Rap is lower quality music and is overrated.
premises: before i get into this, let me be clear what i'm not trying to say : all rap is bad. rap takes no talent. people shouldn't listen to rap at all. people who listen to rap are less intellegent. all the problems i list are exclusive to rap and not other genres of music. ok, now let's get into this : 1. rap uses less people to create, which does not always indicate, but usually indicates less effort overall . obviously, the more people working on something, the more hours that can be put into something. that doesn't mean one person can't create something good, but the likelihood of an individual creating something good is statically less than that of a group. 2. most rap songs use rhymes, which can alter what the creator wants the song to mean . the creator of a song might want to portray a message, express an emotion s , or cause the listener to critically think in some way. since many rap songs rely heavily on rhyming their lyrics, they have to alter the words of the songs in order to rhyme. while this can be entertaining, the meaning of the song is often lost, misunderstood or not taken seriously. 3. rap relies too heavily on vocals and not a variety of instruments . that's not to say that rap never uses anything else, but vocals are always at the forefront; everything but the vocals is just background noise, vocals are emphasized. this means that rap as a genre lacks variety within artists and between artists. it becomes more difficult to distinguish between rap songs, and they start to blend together. this begins to ruin the perception of what's good and what's bad. on top of that, if the vocals are bad, the whole song is bad vs. if one instrument were bad, the entire song is not necessarily ruined. 4. rap is easier to learn than other genres that use other instruments, and most anyone can do it if try tried. there's no hand eye coordination with vocals as with a guitar or piano. on top of that, traditional vocals require the singer to use certain pitches consistently and at loud capacities and to a beat. this makes it easier to learn than other interments or vocals. meaning, people without natural talent can start rapping, and lesser quality songs can be made in abundance. of course, a rapper can spend an equal or greater amount of time practicing as any other musician. but remember, people can also get really good at sitting down and standing up, that doesn't equate to quality. i try to be objective, but i obviously wouldn't be making this argument if i didn't have a bias. i do enjoy some rap, i'm not completely adverse to it. other genres have similar problems, i would say the same of a lot of pop or country music. let me know what you guys think, am i way off base? thanks for reading, i look forward to your responses.
