street late at night. suddenly, a mugger appears out of nowhere and robs him at gunpoint. case b: a man is walking down a busy street. a stranger walks to him seeking for help, describing a life and death situation. on humanitarian grounds, the man follows the stranger who leads him to not so happening street only to realize that it's all a setup. he is then robbed after being held at gun point. now, it is reasonable to state that the ultimate outcome in both of the cases was the man ended up being robbed. however when considered on a profound level, the varying experiences have resulted in different psychological impacts on that person. in case a, it is streetwise to avoid a deserted road to prevent from being taken advantage of. hence, the man would have estimated the probability of getting mugged and made a conscious decision. this would then conform to his existing prejudice about travelling isolated roads at night, which he would definitely avoid in the near future. however an experience from case b would have definitely scarred him by affecting his school of thought towards humanity. it would drive him to a conclusion that it is better off to avoid helping a human or anybody for that matter to avoid the risk of a false case. the next time he sees someone asking for help, even though his conscience would provoke him to provide assistance, his previous experience would say otherwise, thus deterring him from bestowing a respectable act of humanity. on an individual level it would not make a big difference, but consider the impact it would have if hundreds of individuals were robbed in a similar manner. it would then go on to be a preconceived notion that helping somebody en route to an isolated location would have disastrous implications. now imagine the plight of a person asking for help if his case was genuine. statistics suggest that majority of rape victims knew their perpetrators at least at a hierarchical level of an acquaintance. if this keeps on increasing individuals would be wary of accomplices, thus developing trust issues. events like this would make humans lean on individualism and would make them think twice before trusting other humans. and this, as far as the functioning of society is considered, would be the worst thing to happen to it. the basic intention of law is to ensure that humans act in a civilized manner in a society. however what use would the law be if society ceased to exist.

conclusion: The term mansplaining is inherently sexist.
premises: note that i am not denying any sort of institutional or societal sexism towards women that exists or has existed. at the very least it is a term based on a stereotype that may or may not apply to a particular man, though it is used regardless. i am very aware i am on the inside looking out, and do not know what it is like to be on the outside looking in. i am asking this question with the intention of hearing other perspectives so please be my guest and poke holes in what i ve said because i am looking for a greater understanding of the subject and wanted to ask in a place that i know would not be an echo chamber. a few of my thoughts summed up: 1. ken: hey did you hear about janet? she isn t talking to you anymore because you didn t say hi to her last week dan: i figured. janet is always womanciding obviously both men and women are capable of being emotional, so why call it woman ciding? i m sure you can see my point here. 2. both men and women are capable of being condescending, but a man doing it to a woman needs a specific term for it? i think if you break it down the sexism lies in the assumption that a man who is condescending is just an asshole if it s towards a man and sexist if it is towards a woman. 3. why not just use he is condescending or she is condescending because both sexes are capable of being condescending. i feel like if you make a special word for one of them you are being obvious sexist. my whole point is if we say he yelled at her we should also be saying she yelled at her. just like we should be saying she was condescending and he was condescending instead of she was condescending to her vs he was mansplaining to her 4. you don t know if the man you are speaking to is being condescending simply because he is an asshole. this is in effect creating a double standard where the belief is women can freely explain things to men but men cannot freely explain to women under risk of appearing to be a sexist. i don t care for the societal institutional argument where the claim is that sexism hurt women in the workplace and society because men had more power in those roles. i did not do that. i took no part in that and don t know anyone that has. i m sorry if someone you know was hurt by that happening but i had nothing to do with it and if you can associate me with that kind of sexism because of my gender, then you are the sexist one. i am very open to other perspectives and would love to hear what you have to say :

conclusion: Certain private companies like the social media/tech giants should be bound by similar free speech laws as the government.
premises: let me start off by saying i do not think we should tolerate intolerance, but at the same time i am against censorship. these laws exist for very valid reasons, and in some places have a few, also valid, exceptions, such as calling for violence against a person or group. this means that a restaurant for example, can expel guests who are obnoxiously sharing extreme political opinions. now here is where my issue arises. take facebook for example. a social media site with billions of users. whether you agree with it or not, many people get their news from facebook. be it through news outlets posting articles on their pages, or groups sharing them, a very large number of people get their information about a plethora of topics from facebook. due to this fact, facebook has almost unprecedented power over what people can see. what can start off as extreme opinions that call for violence, ie something very clear cut and easy to determine, can slowly erode into something more grey and harder to define like 'no bigotry'. now i know this may seem like a slippery slope argument, but i am not saying it will necessarily turn into this, but simply highlighting that it is possible, and i don't think it should be. if facebook decided to update their policy to exclude things in a more vague way this could have far reaching impacts on the social sphere. there simply aren't any other platforms besides maybe twitter that can compete with facebook in terms of reaching a large audience. if you have an opinion or something you want to share, if you are barred from the widest used social media network, you are cut off from the largest way to share that idea. another perhaps more effective example would be if google skewed search results to favour a certain narrative. if searching something neutral like 'trump' in google brought up almost exclusively negative or positive articles, that would seriously impact how information was shared. google is perhaps the biggest example because they are not only a search engine, but the premier search engine for most people globally. i am aware that this would infringe upon the company's right to do what they want with their own property, but in the circumstances i think it is a reasonable concession.

conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

conclusion: My roommate, who is away for a month, should still pay all flat rate bills for that month
premises: my bills are internet, gas, water, electric, and rent. i have two chief arguments for this. first, him being away does not affect these at all. if i were not living here too, then he would still have to pay all of these fees. by agreeing with these companies to have these services, he locked us into paying at least x per month in service fees. even if we decided that we no longer need water and stopped using it, we would still have to pay these fees for a year. therefore, him not using these services should have no bearing on whether or not he pays the service fees. this is assuming that we mutually agreed to these service, which we did. i would not use this argument if i had purchased cable tv that he did not want to begin with. second, these fees would have to be paid if i also left. for example, if i happened to plan a month long vacation at the same time, we would both be away and both not using these services. however, someone would have to pay the bills. by assuming his argument true, neither of us are responsible for the bills. yet, they must be paid by someone. therefore, using proof by contradiction, i must be correct.

auto_conc: I believe that Borderline Personality Disorder is bullshit.
gt: i don't mean to be rude here, but bpd is a recognized psychiatric disorder and documented in the dsm v the authoritative volume on recognized disorders. that volume is compiled by the most accomplished people in this field, who have spent their lives studying disorders. there are also hundreds of research papers talking about this disorder and its symptoms, which informed the development of the dsm diagnostic criteria. now, that doesn't mean that bpd is correct phrenology was a thing, after all but it is extremely compelling evidence that the disorder is real. if you want to combat the opinions of hundreds of experts in the field, you will need to provide some evidence that these experts are wrong; simply saying 'it isn't real' isn't evidence at all. so, the question is why is your opinion on this more valid than the people who have spent their lives studying this disorder? why are you right and they wrong?

auto_conc: voting by mail removes the concept of a secret ballot
gt: i would argue only one point: it's not that they do or do not matter most of the time they do not it's that you won't know if your vote mattered until after you cast it. most of the time and for most of the american public, for any federal legislator position, your vote is lost in a sea of other votes, and didn't make a discernible difference as the election was heavily skewed to one or the other candidate. you may also live in a state that is heavily leaning in one direction or another, so your agreement or disagreement is basically just background noise. but there are occasions where the election is very close, and your single vote may be among thousands or even hundreds that put someone over the top. and it's not always clear when that will be. two recent examples of such votes were brexit, in which many supporters regretted their vote saying they were 'protest votes' and that they had no expectations it would pass. and the other is hillary vs. trump, where centrists, and liberals assumed hillary had the election locked up and stayed home, whereas the right wing was out in force. states that were blue turned purple, and states that were purple turned red. so yes, votes matter every once in a while, but you'll never know which once in a while until afterwards.

conclusion: The USA should bring back compulsory service
premises: all would be required to serve for some x amount of years. serving in the military should still be available as an option but other accommodations should be made for differing beliefs. if you feel alright about us foreign policy you can do x years in the military, but if you are opposed to it you could do x year serving as a policeman. if you're a pacifist you could do x years serving as an emt for some public hospital or x years in the peace corps. forcing people to serve together in this way would accomplish a couple things: 1 ensures that well trained citizenry is always nearby and ready in case of catastrophe. in a world with this type of service, if a terrorist attack were to occur: 1 4 of all people in the vicinity will be trained soldiers, 1 4 will be trained police, 1 to 2 4 will have some medical training. first responders would already be there because everybody would basically be a first responder. 2 provides young people with something to do. in my mind the service would occur in the 18 22 time frame so that it comes before college. i don't know about any of you but i was someone who went to college because that was just the thing to do. no one had gone before me and that was the route to success, so there i went. it worked for me the debt was real but i got solid job out of it but it doesn't work out for a lot of folks. not only that but asking an 18 year old to decide the institution and career that may define the rest of their lives and saddle them with a mountain of debt seems insane to me. who the fuck knows anything at 18? 3 increases national unity. soldiers peace corp should serve with others from across the country, while police emts should work in parts of the city different form where they live. doing this ensures that all americans are for at least some short time in their lives forced to reckon with their fellow countrymen. besides providing perspective this also helps foster a sense of egalitarianism since it will provide the sense that a citizenship has been 'earned. ' recognition of valid service provides a sort of floor of respectability, which is something that seems sorely lacking these days. 4 it is a project that is unachievable in the free market. while one can imagine how organizations such as the ymca given the proper incentives could establish a role in a society as a pre college and service like pillar, it comes with some tricky issues. a private institution training soldiers and policemen is a break in the government monopoly on violence which i think most people agree is necessary for a functional government . a private institution is accountable to whoever funds it, moral or no, while a public institution would at least by law be held accountable to the voters. and the idea of charging money for things that the peace corps does just seems wrong. so, cmv. tbh i've always been okay with the idea of a draft in it's most raw form but i figure this might make it more palatable for people who don't.

you make someone serve at a hospital does not mean they will remember cpr for their whole life which is why that certification requires frequent update. i learned spanish for 3 years in highschool and don't remember a damn thing. especially if people aren't interested in it because they are being made to do it, they probably won't retain a lot of that training for very long2. yes. but some young be a chemical engineer. after 2 years if engineering school i decided i would wrong, and i wanted to be a software engineer. i wouldn't have been able to make that decision serving in any of the fields you mentioned3. it sounds like you're going to force a lot of people away from home. for me, i wouldn't mind, but a lot of people will be really rattled by this. just a thought. i do agree that as i know . perhaps the other fields could benefit from more people but as far as i know, we are still fine in those areas too. 3. i don't like the concept of being required to serve your country. maybe this is a personal thing. but you didn't ask to be born here and for most people there's nothing you can do about it. requiring someone to do service without their consent, to me, is a human rights violation. and i know some countries do this, and i oppose that greatly

' i believe the attitude should instead be more along the lines of, 'blacks should be proud of how empowered they've become despite societal oppression. so keep using it. we don't care because it only shows the leaps and bounds they've made in recent decades. ' we don't use 'the c word' for chink or 'the c word' for cracker. in fact, especially stigmatizing the nword over other racial slurs seems to send a message that other racial slurs are more ok when they should all be equally frowned upon in colloquial language.
